—My question is to the Minister for Defence and Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Robert Hill. Will the minister outline to the Senate any progress that has been made in relation to two major shipbuilding projects: the air warfare destroyer and the amphibious ships projects? What additional capability will these projects provide to the Australian Defence Force?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
talker.role: Minister for Defence
talker.name: Senator HILL

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Trood for his first question and congratulate him. He comes with impressive qualifications in international affairs and defence and he will be a great asset to the Senate. I am pleased to announce today that the federal government has chosen Gibbs and Cox as the preferred designer for the $6 billion Air Warfare Destroyer Project—one of Australia’s largest and most complex defence projects. The selection of Gibbs and Cox as the platform designer now completes the team whose responsibility it is to deliver the Air Warfare Destroyer Project. Gibbs and Cox will join alliance partners ASC Shipbuilder Pty Ltd and Raytheon Australia, who will work together over the next phase of the project.

answer.para: Gibbs and Cox was chosen through a competitive tender evaluation process that also included the German company Blohm and Voss and the Spanish company Navantia. Gibbs and Cox has been chosen to further develop an evolved design. Navantia will remain in the competition as the designer of an Australianised version of the existing F100 design. The two designs will be considered by the government before final project approval in 2007.

This announcement closely follows the government’s approval of the first stage of the $2 billion amphibious ships project, which will provide the Navy with a world-class capability to deploy land forces on operations. Australian shipbuilders will be invited to tender for either or both of two very capable designs. The two designs are a Spanish Navantia ship at approximately 27,000 tonnes and a French Armaris Mistral ship with an additional troop-carrying capability at approximately 22,000 tonnes. A request for tender will be released in the second quarter of 2006. The preferred shipbuilder will be determined once a thorough financial and technical comparison is made between Australian bids and the overseas build options.

These new ships represent a quantum leap in the amphibious lift and air warfare capabilities of the Navy and will enter service from 2012 and 2013 respectively. The air warfare destroyers will deliver an area air warfare capability that will be able to provide air defence for other ADF assets including forces ashore and friendly aircraft against hostile aircraft and missiles over large areas. This control of the sea and air will give Australia, through an amphibious capability that will include embarked troop lift and armed reconnaissance helicopters, the ability to lift, lodge, sustain and withdraw a combined arms battle group consisting of an embarked force of up to 2,000 personnel and their vehicles and equipment wherever the government determines.

Together these capabilities will ensure that the ADF maintains sufficient flexibility to provide military response options to a wide range of contingencies including evacuation of Australian nationals overseas, humanitarian assistance missions, the protection of our vital maritime trading routes and warlike operations. The government is delivering on its $50 billion decade-long plan to provide the ADF of the future with the best possible equipment to do its job. National security will remain of the highest priority to the Howard government. I would like to thank Defence, which is progressing these major projects in a very professional and responsible way.

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Coonan, the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. I refer the minister to the latest OECD figures which rank Australia 21st out of 30 developed countries for broadband use. Is the minister aware that Australian consumers are paying up to three times as much as Korean consumers to access a high-speed broadband connection? Is the minister also aware that entry-level broadband products in Canada are six times faster, allow 30 times the amount of downloads and are 10 per cent cheaper than the equivalent Australian product? In light of these facts, does the minister now understand why Telstra CEO Mr Trujillo told his board that Australia is in the bottom quartile of developed countries in terms of its telecommunications services?

talker.name: Coonan, Sen Helen
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts
talker.name: Senator COONAN

talk.start.para: —Thank you, Senator McEwen, for the question. I do not know whether it is the first one, Senator, but thank you for the question anyway. As I said in response to a question asked by Senator Conroy, the OECD figures I have show that Australia has now moved into 10th position on the rate of take-up of broadband, because broadband in this country is growing exponentially. What you will find, if you have a look at the figures, is that we now have about two million subscribers to broadband, whereas about a year ago it was a much smaller figure. This has largely been driven by the fact that consumers have become aware of the great benefits of broadband and how it enables them to live, work and do business in a way that they could not with slower dial-up services.

answer.para: The figures show that, particularly in populous areas, there is a range of ways in which broadband can be provided over different platforms with different technologies. That is precisely how consumers get choice, competition and lower prices. Then, when you move to areas where it is uncommercial for these services to be provided, and because the government is interested in areas of market failure and in preserving competitive neutrality, all service providers get an opportunity to provide it in these noncommercial areas with a subsidy from the government. What the subsidy means is that people in rural and regional areas can get these valuable services at comparable prices to those in the more populous areas.

What I would say to Senator McEwen is: it is a very sketchy case indeed to say that this country is not able to access broadband pretty much right across the country at reasonable speeds. Senator McEwen is lucky that she was not here when the Labor Party, in a never-to-be-forgotten Senate report, recommended to this government that they spend $5 billion on mandating dial-up internet. If ever there would have been a way to do the taxpayers’ dough, Senator McEwen would have seen that written large in the Senate committee report. In answer to her question: this government, because of its subsidies, has ensured that broadband is available across the country. We will continue to look after services in rural and regional Australia and we will ensure that no Australian is left behind in telecommunications.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. When will the government stop applying broadband bandaids like HiBIS and instead take the tough decisions to improve competition in the broadband market? After nine long years, will the government now make a communications decision in the interests of the Australian economy instead of simply for the benefit of the government’s extreme agenda of privatising Telstra?

talker.name: Coonan, Sen Helen
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts
talker.name: Senator COONAN

talk.start.para: —In response to the supplementary question, I assume that Senator McEwen is aware that this government has recently had an inquiry into the state of the competition regime in Australia and that discussions have been going on for some weeks, probably months, as to whether or not there should be a form of operational separation for Telstra because of its vertical integration. That, together with other responses that the government will have under consideration as a result of that inquiry, will ensure that this government continue to have a very sound and very robust competition regime. This of course is in contradistinction to the Labor Party, whose best response to this was to slice and dice Telstra. That was Mr Tanner’s plan, and I noticed that he is at it again. Mr Tanner, the real opposition spokesman on telecommunications, is back to his old tricks.

—My question is to the Minister for Finance and Administration, Senator Minchin, representing the Treasurer. Will the minister inform the Senate of recent indicators of expenditure on infrastructure in Australia? Is the minister aware of any alternative proposals in relation to infrastructure policy?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
talker.role: Minister for Finance and Administration
talker.name: Senator MINCHIN

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Brandis for that question. We do hear occasionally from self-interested commentators in the opposition that there is some sort of infrastructure crisis in Australia and that we should be putting a whole lot more federal government money into infrastructure. Against that backdrop, it was interesting to read the June quarter Investment Monitor from Access Economics. That report outlined major capital projects in Australia, either planned or under way, totalling no less than $375 billion just in the June quarter this year—up 16 per cent on the same period a year ago. We not only have this large number of projects under way, but there is a very big pipeline of projects coming down the track.

answer.para: The figures on actual quarterly infrastructure spending tell the same story. The engineering construction figures from the ABS show that engineering expenditure grew by seven per cent in the March quarter and 12 per cent over the year. In the March quarter of 1996, when we came to office, engineering expenditure was $3.6 billion. In the March quarter this year, it is $8.3 billion. That is an increase of 82 per cent under our government in real terms. Similarly, when we came to office, the market cap of listed infrastructure funds on the ASX was less than $1 billion, and today it is $27 billion. All these statistics go to show that this talk of a crisis is nonsense and that, in fact, there are large increases in infrastructure spending going on in this very strong economy.

Against that backdrop, it was interesting to hear Mr Beazley say last June that he was going to campaign on this issue throughout the winter recess. He did not say what his policy was or which projects he thought should be funded either by the public or by the private sector, so we waited in eager anticipation to see this campaign in the winter recess and to hear about his plans and policies for infrastructure in this country. We did not see a lot from Mr Beazley on any issue in the winter recess, but then, on 1 August, right towards the end of the winter recess, the Financial Review reported that Labor’s policy on this very important matter was to form a committee and to have a year-long inquiry into the subject. The chairman of this committee was to be none other than the infamous former Queensland Labor apparatchik, Mike Kaiser—whom we know all about—and the deputy chairman was going to be the National Secretary of the CFMEU. According to the Financial Review, this committee was going to be looking into ‘issuing special government bonds’. What that means is increasing debt, which of course was the way they ran their government last time, when debt rose by $66 billion in their last five years in government.

Labor are also apparently going to consider setting up public interest corporations, presumably like WA Inc., Tricontinental in Victoria and the Victorian Economic Development Corporation. This suggests that Labor simply have not learned anything from their nine years in opposition—absolutely nothing at all. This is clearly the old Left, which Senator Conroy keeps trying to beat, back in charge of Labor’s policy. When they do not have a policy, what they do—as they do on so many subjects—is to set up an inquiry, put a few apparatchiks in charge, go away and come back with all the Socialist Left rhetoric.

talk.start.para: —I am on the committee.

—Senator Conroy is on the committee, but clearly in the minority. They will come back with all these risky approaches: ‘let’s increase debt’, ‘let’s increase government funding’. This was the Labor agenda of the 1980s. This produced the Bannon, Burke and Cain government disasters—which of course are now all back in the media in Western Australia and make fascinating reading for the government.

—My question is to Senator Vanstone, the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs. Is the minister aware of reports at the weekend that Senator Ross Lightfoot advised visitors to make false asylum claims to avoid the consequences of staying in Australia after their visas had expired? Is it the case that Immigration officials believed the Aziz family had no basis for seeking asylum, including the fact that they were actually residents of the United Arab Emirates? Hasn’t the minister constantly asserted that only genuine asylum claims, and not false claims, would be considered by her department? Don’t Senator Lightfoot’s actions fly in the face of this commitment?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Indigenous Affairs
talker.name: Senator VANSTONE

talk.start.para: —I thank the senator for the question. The advice I have about the people concerned is that the woman was first granted a visa to accompany her husband to Australia in August 2003. She applied for a waiver of the ‘no further stay’ condition in November 2003. The request for waiver of the ‘no further stay’ condition was refused, and two bridging visas were issued. She complied with all the visa requirements and departed Australia in January 2004, before her visa expired.

answer.para: Subsequently, in January 2004, she applied for a visa to visit her brother, which was granted. I can confirm that Senator Lightfoot provided written assurance that he believed that Ms Amin would not apply for protection as a refugee if she was granted a further stay as a visitor. She complied with all visa requirements and departed Australia in June 2004, before her visa expired. To date, no record of an application for protection by Ms Amin has been located. Members of parliament from all parties regularly make representations to the department, and to the minister, on behalf of individuals seeking a certain migration outcome. That is their right. Many would say it is the obligation of members of parliament who believe in a particular cause.

I hope the suggestion is not that, if someone puts in a protection visa claim, I should not look at it and any representations from members of parliament. If that is the Labor Party view, please tell me. When I get representations from people on the other side in relation to people who have come here as students or whatever and later decided to put a protection visa claim in, if you do not think I should listen to them, I will be happy to take that into account.

If we also want to talk about members making representations, I had a bit of a chance to reflect on history the other day as I was reading the Herald Sun. On page 22 there was an article headed, ‘Forty years of favours’. It reminds members with a shorter memory that Mr Grassby—who at one stage was immigration minister—according to the Herald, while in Italy arranged the issue of entry permits to Australia for three members of the Barbaro family, who had previously been denied entry on the grounds of bad character. One of them had previously been deported from Australia. Italian police had arrested one of them when he returned to Plati and charged him with having kidnapped the teenage son of an industrialist four months before. Mr Grassby also, according to the article, made representations to the Treasurer on behalf of Tony Sergi over Sergi’s tax problems. Sergi was named four years later by the Woodward royal commission as a principal of the Griffith ‘honoured society’ and a major marijuana grower.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. It is a matter of relevance. The minister attempted to answer the first part of the question but has now subsequently strayed quite a way from the question. I would ask you to bring her back to the question that I have asked. If she has nothing further to say in respect of that, she could sit down.
—Senator Vanstone, you have a minute left to answer that question. I remind you of the question.

—The question went to a particular member of parliament, what advice he had offered people in relation to migration matters and whether he had used his office to assist them in any way. That is the nub of the question. I have answered that question. In fact, the department does not have a record of a particular person making a protection claim. This is another furphy, an allegation that has been dragged through the papers. As I understand it, at this point we have not been able to find a protection visa claim. The woman left Australia, unlike a lot of people on whose behalf people on the other side send me representations, who do not leave when they are meant to leave. All I was doing was making the point that senators and members are entitled to make representations and drawing on a little history of former Labor minister Grassby, who did make representations on behalf of a number of people of some particular interest. I have nothing further to add than that.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I understand the minister has checked the records in relation to the Aziz family. Can the minister confirm, firstly, whether or not Senator Lightfoot has made any other submissions to her department or the office in relation to this or similar cases which might encourage the use of the types of tactics that were alleged in that article? Secondly, can the minister rule out that that article had any substance in it?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Indigenous Affairs
talker.name: Senator VANSTONE

talk.start.para: —If we want to go through the process of asking Immigration to go through every file to see which members have made representations to it and waste all that time and money, I suppose we could look at doing that. I have answered the question. I have indicated that members are entitled to make representations. I have said ‘no’ to representations made by very senior people on my side. I have said ‘yes’ to very new people, not on the front bench, on the other side. In other words, when it comes to ministerial intervention, things are considered on their merits, and I believe exactly the same is done in the department.

—My question is to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, Senator Vanstone. Will the minister inform the Senate of progress in finalising the first regional partnership agreement with an Indigenous community, and is the minister aware of any alternative policies in this area?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Indigenous Affairs
talker.name: Senator VANSTONE

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Payne for the question. Senator Payne, like all senators on this side and many on the other side, has a longstanding interest in the benefit of first Australians and what we can all do to improve the life opportunities and choices for them. Our first regional partnership agreement with an Indigenous community was signed in Warburton in Western Australia on Friday. Sadly, I was unable to be there, but Minister Cobb represented me. Three shared responsibility agreements were also signed. With these agreements, the Australian government makes an agreement directly with a community, not by asking for someone with a clipboard to be there speaking on its behalf.

answer.para: They were signed by the Western Australian government, the Ngaanyatjarraku shire and the community council. They involve about $8 million from the Australian government, funding from the Western Australian government and contributions in cash and in kind from the communities. The regional partnership agreement is a very important step in the government’s reforms for Indigenous affairs. While the shared responsibility agreements focus on local communities, regional ones provide a much better avenue for strategic partnerships between the governments and the regional representative bodies.

The regional partnership agreement in this case covers 12 communities and over three years will provide support for the council to work with local communities and governments to achieve better outcomes and better ways to improve power and provide municipal services that the rest of us take for granted. I thank Senator Patterson’s department for contributing over $4 million to this. There is also provision for education for young adults and a youth centre. A number of Commonwealth agencies were involved, and I am pleased that the Western Australian government was involved and that Minister Kobelke was able to travel to Warburton and be a part of this very important ceremony.

These are basically well-governed communities. They have their problems, but they are tackling them head on. They are taking responsibility and doing something about them, giving us their view and getting ahead on their own. They have their own word for the concept of shared responsibility and mutual obligation. I am told they describe it as ‘chuck in, chuck in’. I am not sure that everyone understands the translation of that, but it means you put in and others put in, and that is what these agreements are about—everybody putting in. ‘Chuck in, chuck in’ will do.

In petrol sniffing it is interesting to see what has happened in the Warburton area. In the eighties and nineties there was a very big petrol-sniffing problem in this area. The community leaders have worked very hard to do what they can about it. They introduced their own by-laws in this area, I am told, in 1992 to provide penalties for trafficking and sniffing. They ensured that the by-laws were enforced. They introduced diversionary programs. They converted to avgas in 1996. And now the petrol sniffing problem has dramatically improved from what it was. When I was told about this over the weekend—because this information came, obviously, from my staff who were at this function—I asked, ‘How many people? Do they put one or two in jail?’ I was told that one week they put 30 people in jail. They do not back away from it as a community. They say, ‘We’ve got to do something about this.’ Mutujulu, of course, is in a different situation. It needs a lot more help.

So in answer to Senator Payne’s question: yes, there are very significant improvements happening. Communities are taking responsibility and sharing responsibility with the Commonwealth government, with state governments and with regional areas. But they are all very different. In Warburton they are doing a lot to help themselves. In Mutujulu it is going to be up to us and the relevant state government to get in and do some more and help. It is a community in crisis. We are putting more money in. We are putting a community worker in there, hopefully, to get local people together to restore some capacity and restore some hope. Nine women from that community have participated in our women’s leadership program. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Family and Community Services. Is the minister aware of the South Australian Justice Mullighan commission of inquiry into children in state care? Is the minister aware that so far 780 people have made allegations saying they were victims of sexual assault and abuse while they were in state care in South Australia? Does the minister agree that one universal truth established by the Senate inquiries into children in care is that, if you harm a child, you end up with a harmed adult? Does the minister agree that the long-term social and economic costs consequent to harming children mean that it is far cheaper and better to do the right thing by kids than to try and address later adult problems? Is the government monitoring state inquiries such as the Mullighan inquiry to help it coordinate good child welfare systems with the states?

talker.name: Patterson, Sen Kay
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Women’s Issues
talker.name: Senator PATTERSON

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Murray for the question. I know he has had a deep and abiding interest in this issue and I know that senators on all sides of the house were moved and shocked by the stories that they heard as people presented to both the reports—Forgotten Australians and Protecting vulnerable children. I know that Senator McLucas and Senator Knowles both talked to me about these issues and Senator Knowles particularly in depth—because she is on my side of the chamber; I am not saying that Senator McLucas would not, but Senator Knowles expressed her concern as people were coming and bringing reports.

answer.para: As I am sure Senator Murray is aware, child protection is primarily the responsibility of the states and territories, and many of the recommendations in both of those reports need to be responded to either by state and territory jurisdictions or by churches and charitable organisations. Unfortunately, some of the damage that has been done in the past can never be undone. As Senator Murray has said, when a child is damaged, the child, as he or she grows up into an adult, takes with himself or herself the scars and the legacy of that abuse—abuse that should not have occurred when children were in state care or in the care of church or other organisations. It beggars belief that that did happen.

We are aware of the South Australian Children in State Care Commission of Inquiry, headed by Commissioner Mullighan. It is, as Senator Murray has indicated, state based. It is investigating allegations of sexual abuse and criminal misconduct against children who were in institutional care or foster care in South Australia. We consider it appropriate for state and territory governments to pursue these issues and I hope that other states will look at what South Australia is doing and take a lead from that.

We are considering our response to the two Senate reports. As I said, many of the responses to the recommendations really require a state response. We hope to provide a response to those two reports by the end of the year but, as I said, it does require a much more concerted effort on the part of the states and on the part of the charitable and church organisations that were responsible for the institutions in which these children suffered sexual and/or emotional abuse.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for her answer. Does the minister accept that a reign of terror occurred in too many child-care institutions, resulting in thousands of suicides, many tens of thousands of sexual assaults, hundreds of thousands of physical assaults and consequent trauma for many of the adults those children became? Does the minister therefore recognise there is a need to get on with the job? While I and she recognise that it is a very complex issue, the government needs to respond to the recommendations. So I ask the minister: can she give the chamber any indication of when the government is likely to be able to respond to the unanimous recommendations of Forgotten Australians?

talker.name: Patterson, Sen Kay
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Women’s Issues
talker.name: Senator PATTERSON

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Murray. As I have said and I will say again, the vast majority of the recommendations require a response from the states. It is an issue that I raised again with the relevant state ministers when I met with them a few weeks ago in Alice Springs, indicating that we need to move on this issue. CLAN, the Care Leavers of Australia Network, one of the organisations that have been involved in leading this issue, came to me last year and indicated that they required some assistance with counselling. I immediately provided $100,000 for them to seek counselling. There was a little delay in that money being used, I might add, and I raised that with CLAN. They have now rectified that and they advised me, as we passed each other in the corridor today—because I could not attend the meeting that they were having, although Sussan Ley attended—that they have now got a counsellor. But, as I said, the bulk of the response to both inquiries really needs to come from the state governments and the charitable and church organisations. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Special Minister of State, Senator Abetz, representing the Minister for Small Business and Tourism. Is the minister aware of new evidence about the failure of the current unfair dismissal laws to protect Australian workers and small business? Is the minister aware of any other policies?

talker.name: Abetz, Sen Eric
talker.role: Special Minister of State
talker.name: Senator ABETZ

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Ferris for her question and acknowledge her longstanding interest in workplace relations reform. I am indeed aware of new evidence which demonstrates the abject failure of the Keating government’s unfair unfair dismissal laws experiment. A new survey of 900 businesses released earlier this week provides further evidence of this failed experiment. The survey found that a massive 65 per cent of businesses had experienced, or known of, speculative unfair dismissal claims by workers. Further, 37 per cent said the practice of paying go-away money occurred regularly and another 30 per cent said it happened occasionally. Given these facts, one wonders if Labor is now willing to accept the problem of go-away money. It would be interesting to hear from them now. They have suddenly gone quiet when they have been given the challenge of saying whether or not they accept the problem of go-away money.

answer.para: I will not ask Senator Hutchins as to who said, ‘Labor has long acknowledged the issue of go-away money.’ So Labor now acknowledges it. The chances are Senator Marshall might be able to tell us now, with some of the unions wanting him to go away. The person that said, ‘Labor has long acknowledged the issue of go-away money’ was in fact Joel Fitzgibbon, the shadow spokesman for small business. Labor knows of the problem; it admits to it, but it is unwilling to do anything about it. Interestingly enough, Mr Fitzgibbon says the reason it does not want to do anything about the unfair dismissal laws is that it is:

quote.para: ... likely to be worse for small business operators because many of the vexatious claimants will take the ‘unlawful dismissal’ path.

answer.para: The unlawful dismissal path is in fact the path that those on the other side claim will not protect workers in any shape or form. Now they are claiming that it in fact will protect workers and, what is more, the laws are so loose that the vexatious claimants will simply slip from the unfair dismissal law regime into the unlawful dismissal regime.

This sort of tortured logic I suppose has to be expected from Mark Latham’s best friend. But I say to those opposite with great respect: if you want to suggest yourselves to the Australian people as an alternative government, you have to come up with policies that actually gel—policies that actually make sense. You cannot assert one thing on one hand and then the exact opposite on the other. The Labor Party are scrambling around for justifications not to support our very important reforms for unfair dismissal. Until the Labor Party are ready to do something about the problem that they themselves acknowledge, they are not ready nor are they fit for government of this great country.

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Minchin, representing the Treasurer. Can the minister explain why households paid an average 29 per cent more a year on credit card fees between 2001 and 2004, or nine times the rate of inflation? Is the minister aware that in 1997 Australian families paid $168 a year in bank fees? Can the minister tell the Senate how much families now pay each year in bank fees and what are the reasons for the change?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
talker.role: Minister for Finance and Administration
talker.name: Senator MINCHIN

talk.start.para: —I have some information here on bank fees which I am happy to share with the Senate. The result of the survey of bank fees done by the Reserve Bank for 2004 was released in May. That indicates that growth in banks’ domestic fee income grew by in fact only four per cent in 2004, the lowest in the survey’s eight-year history and one-third the rate from the previous year. That was largely due to a sharp fall in merchant service fees for credit cards resulting from the RBA’s reforms to credit card interchange fees. Other sources of fee income grew in line with the pace of recent years. Recent increases in banks’ fee revenue stem from increases in the use of banking services—which, presumably, we welcome—which is evident in the higher number of customer accounts and associated transactions and is not necessarily due to higher charges per transaction. Of course, consumers also continue to benefit from the decline in banks’ lending margins since the mid-1990s, which has more than offset fee increases.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I am told that I should not believe this. All I can do is believe the figures that come from the RBA which, as I say, show that growth in banks’ domestic fee income was only four per cent in 2004. So I think customers and consumers are well served by the Australian banking industry, one of the strongest and most reputable industries in Australia. Australia is extremely well served by its reputable, responsible and competitive banking industry.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Isn’t it true that families are now paying $447 a year in bank fees, which is up from $168 in 1997? Can the minister explain why, when bank fees are eating up a larger and larger share of family budgets, they will only be included in the consumer price inflation measure for the first time towards the end of this year?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
talker.role: Minister for Finance and Administration
talker.name: Senator MINCHIN

talk.start.para: —I have rebutted the premise to the question, which is this argument that there is this massive increase in bank fees. I have just outlined what the increase is. It was only four per cent in 2004, so this is a hysterical and nonsensical proposition from the opposition. As to the question of its inclusion in the CPI, I would need further information on that matter.

—My question is to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Senator Campbell. It relates to the propriety of the federal government’s administration of the new federal heritage regime. I ask: can the minister explain why, in an apparent breach of his statutory responsibilities under the EPBC Act, he decided not to make a decision on the nomination of Sir Don Bradman’s birthplace in the lead-up to the 2004 federal election yet he made a decision at the same time to list the Kurnell Peninsula? Can he further explain why $50,000 was subsequently granted to the Cootamundra Shire Council for the Australian Cricket Captains Walk when no funding application had been lodged? If the purpose of the new heritage regime is to focus on places of national significance, how can the minister justify his decisions on the Bradman and Kurnell projects whilst refusing an emergency listing of Recherche Bay in Tasmania?

talker.name: Campbell, Sen Ian
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage
talker.name: Senator IAN CAMPBELL

talk.start.para: —Thank you for the question. It is a very important question. Firstly, in relation to the listing of Bradman’s birthplace—I think it was the very first part of the question—I did check, because I have had inquiries from a newspaper already today about this, and was told that the advice from the Australian Heritage Council on the listing of Bradman’s birthplace at Cootamundra was not received by me and was not even issued by the AHC until 29 October, which was at least a fortnight after the election. So the reality is that I could not have acted upon that. The advice was not to list it. I have to say, not as a passionate cricket historian or follower as my great Prime Minister is but as someone who does follow it—I did actually try to stay up and watch the test—

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! The Senate will come to order.

—I did in fact try to stay up to watch those great Australians hold up their end. Congratulations to Ricky Ponting for his knock. My good friend and neighbour from Subiaco Adam Gilchrist did not perform quite so well but I am sure he will do better in the next test.

answer.para: In relation to Bradman’s birthplace, I was a bit shocked by the AHC’s advice not to list it. It seemed on the face of it a very obvious thing to list but, on reading the details and the reasons that it should not be, I thought there was some merit in their arguments. After lobbying from Kay Hull MP and from Alby Schultz MP, I did seek to find a way to commemorate Bradman’s unique place in Australia’s history and Australia’s sporting heritage. I did start working on the concept of a Bradman trail, something that the department strongly supported. We needed to find funding for parts of that Bradman trail, which now is established through Cootamundra, Bowral and Adelaide, which I am sure many South Australians will be pleased to know. I asked the department to find funding for aspects of that trail. As I understand it, the Sharing Australia’s Stories program was identified as an appropriate source of funding.

In relation to Kurnell, that site was up for emergency listing. Bruce Baird MP may have nominated it for listing, but I think all Australians would have shared the member for Cook’s dedication to that fact that the first place, if I understand my history, where Captain Cook set foot on Australian soil is important. It is a place that is important not just to Bruce Baird but to all Australians. I was very pleased to emergency list that.

I find it interesting that the Greens would seek to attack a decision to place an emergency listing, which ultimately led to an Australian Heritage Listing, of Captain Cook’s first place of setting foot on Australian soil, that they should seek to condemn me for funding the commemoration of Don Bradman and that they should then seek to further criticise me in relation to Recherche Bay, which I currently have before me. I think it is a very important decision. I think where D’Entrecasteaux landed in Australia for a few weeks back in 1792 and then again in 1793 are important parts of Australia’s maritime history. I have it before me at the moment. Since they seem intent on criticising decisions to recognise Captain Cook and Don Bradman, I wonder what third great Australian and what decision they might criticise in future, but I am sure a supplementary question will reveal that answer.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. What role did the Prime Minister’s office play in the decision to give $50,000 to the Australian Cricket Captains Walk? Was the Prime Minister’s office consulted or in any way involved in the decision not to emergency list the internationally significant cultural site at Recherche Bay in Tasmania in the face of logging? I asked the minister to explain why he did not emergency list when logging was imminent but was prepared to emergency list another place which quite well deserved protection—but the issue is about why he chose one and not the other. Finally, will the government now transfer responsibility for assessing sites and distributing funds for heritage projects to an independent statutory authority?

talker.name: Campbell, Sen Ian
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage
talker.name: Senator IAN CAMPBELL

talk.start.para: —The Australian Heritage Council, which is chaired by Tom Harley and has a number of eminent Australians on it, have given me advice in relation to Recherche Bay. They have said that, yes, there are heritage values at that site. I have visited the site. There is no doubt about it. I have read the history of it. But they also advised me that it was not under threat—that those values were not under threat—and therefore emergency heritage listing would not be required. Just because Senator Brown or Senator Milne want to create a bit of a publicity stunt around something does not mean that it is of any more important heritage value than something else. I will make a decision on Recherche at the right time for the right reasons—not because some Green from Tasmania wants to make a political stunt about it.
—My question is to the Minister for Defence, Senator Hill. I note that the minister in his previous answer did not refer to his election promise of 5 October 2004 where he said:

quote.para: ... both the ... Air Warfare Destroyers and the ... Amphibious Ships will be built in Australia by Australian workers.

question.para: Given this ironclad election commitment, why did the minister say last week:

quote.para: The Government’s preference is to see the ships built in Australia. However, Australian industry will need to demonstrate it can deliver the project at a competitive price.

question.para: Is the minister also aware that his office has since attempted to deny that the government’s election promise was ever made? Can the minister now indicate why the government has broken its clear election promise to build the amphibious ships in Australia?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
talker.role: Minister for Defence
talker.name: Senator HILL

talk.start.para: —I congratulate the honourable senator on her first question—a searching and demanding question on an important subject. The important subject is the employment of Australian labour in the defence arena. Yes, this government is very committed to building Australian defence industry. The two shipbuilding projects that I have referred to will give enormous opportunities for growth in terms of naval shipbuilding capabilities. That is, of course, across a whole range of trades and specialties.

answer.para: In relation to the amphibious ship project—building the two large amphibious ships—yes, it is our wish that they be built in Australia. That is why we have extended the schedule for a period of two years to allow Australian industry to bid and to compete with the very competitive bids that have been made by overseas shipyards. I guess the distinction between Labor and this side of the chamber is that we always say: ‘Not at any price.’ On the Labor Party side, they always say: ‘At any price: drive up debt, drive up borrowings, send the country broke, put a million Australians out of work,’ as they did on the last occasion when they were in government. That is the reckless, irresponsible approach of the Labor Party, which was true when they were in government and remains true today.

We on this side of the chamber say: ‘Yes, build in Australia, but we expect Australian industry to be competitive.’ Australian industry tell me they will be competitive. Australian industry assure me that they can construct these ships at a price competitive with any overseas shipyard. That is why we are giving them the opportunity to do so. It is our preference that they be built in this country. It is our preference that they be built here and maintained here, and I am confident that they will meet the charge that is given to them.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister indicate what would be the likely impact if the amphibious ships were built overseas rather than in Australia? Would any Australian shipbuilding yards be forced to close? How many jobs would be lost if that were to happen? Why, Minister, won’t you restate your commitment of 5 October 2004 and give an absolute guarantee that the amphibious ships will be built in Australia by Australian workers?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
talker.role: Minister for Defence
talker.name: Senator HILL

talk.start.para: —I can only repeat what I have said: we want these ships to be built in Australia and we want them to be built at a competitive price. Price is important to us, because otherwise you send the country broke. That is what Labor can never understand.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! I remind Senator Evans and other senators that shouting across the chamber is disorderly. Senator Hill.
—I have answered the question.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I invite you to cast your eyes to the left of the chair. There is somebody who now very studiously has his eyes focused on the desk, as well he might, but his interventions during question time, especially to the leader, trying to attract his attention to alleged quotes and other behaviour, were completely unacceptable. If you want to join the Senate, you ought to seek preselection. They could do with extra talent!
—Senator Abetz, I will keep an eye on advisers on both sides of the chair and will warn them accordingly.

—My question is to the Minister for Justice and Customs, Senator Ellison. Will the minister update the Senate on measures being taken by the government to enhance the Australian Customs Service’s maritime capability and to ensure the security of our borders?

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
talker.role: Minister for Justice and Customs
talker.name: Senator ELLISON

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Johnston for a very important question which is vital to all Australians, particularly to the north of our continent. Recently in Broome I had the pleasure of commissioning the first installation of the 7.62-millimetre gun on the Australian Customs vessel the Corio Bay. This will be rolled out at a cost of $25 million to all our Customs vessels and will give our Customs vessels that extra resource that they need in carrying out the very good work that they do in looking out for Australia’s borders. We need this sort of armament if they are to guard against incursions into our borders.

answer.para: In particular, I mention fishing, which is a matter of concern to the north of our country at the moment. I support fully the actions of my colleague Senator Ian Macdonald, the Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation, in this regard. Of course Customs works in a partnership with Navy, Air Force and Coastwatch in looking out for our borders. I was pleased to see that just the other day the HMAS Bendigo apprehended three foreign vessels suspected of fishing illegally in Australian waters. That demonstrates yet again the partnership between Navy and Customs. In relation to this initiative, we will see extra Customs crew on our Customs vessels. I remind senators that our Customs vessels, which are doing such a great job, were built in Western Australia.

Recently on a visit to Indonesia I raised the question of border control with my Indonesian counterparts. I must say that the level of cooperation that we are receiving from Indonesian authorities is at an all-time high. Recently in the Operation Clear Water exercise to the north we had Indonesian officials participating for the first time. We have invited them to repeat that in the next exercise that we will be conducting. As well as that, the Customs officer that we now have in Jakarta has participated in operations with Indonesia and also in carrying out border training techniques and other related initiatives. This is vitally important if we are to manage our borders to the north of Australia. Not only do we have to look after our border perimeters but we have to engage with our neighbours in ensuring that we manage those incursions which are occurring, particularly in relation to the question of illegal fishing. That was a subject that I discussed with my counterparts in Indonesia, and it is one that they recognised as an issue for themselves as well.

Our approach to border control is one of providing the resources to the men and women who do such a great job in looking after Australia’s borders and also engaging in the region with our neighbours to ensure that we can approach this in a partnership to look at how, together, we can govern our border in the sense of a regional initiative. I might add that this initiative follows on from the arming of the Oceanic Viking with a .50-calibre machine gun. That patrols the Southern Ocean, looking out for our sovereign waters and doing such a great job. Again I point to the great work that we are doing in partnership with other countries, such as France, who also patrol those areas.

This has been a whole-of-government approach, from Senator Ian Macdonald with the fishing aspect right through to border control involving Navy, Air Force, Customs, Coastwatch and Fisheries. This is how we approach looking after Australia’s borders: as a whole-of-government initiative. The runs are on the board.

talk.start.para: —My question is also to Senator Ellison, the Minister for Justice and Customs. Is the minister aware of last night’s revelations on ABC’s Four Corners program that Australians’ private and confidential data is for sale, sourced from call centres—in this case in India—which have been subcontracted to provide services to Australian financial institutions? Does the data for sale include ATM card numbers, Medicare numbers, drivers licence numbers, telephone numbers, birth certificate details and, in one case, a passport number? Have the Australian Federal Police been asked to investigate this matter? If not, why not? If the Federal Police are investigating, can the minister indicate whether their report will be made public and when this will happen?

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
talker.role: Minister for Justice and Customs
talker.name: Senator ELLISON

talk.start.para: —The question of breach of privacy is dealt with quite separately from any action by the AFP. The Privacy Commissioner has the power to deal with that matter which relates to personal information of Australian people who may be the victims. In relation to the question of whether the Australian Federal Police is looking at it, I can say that the Australian Federal Police is. It is assessing information which has been provided to it. I might say that information was provided to the AFP by staff involved in the Four Corners program. That course of action is one that I endorse fully, rather than simply having a report on TV or in the print media and then leaving it there. I endorse the course of action Four Corners took in this regard in taking to the Australian Federal Police the information that it had. That is now being assessed by the Australian Federal Police. I remind the Senate that there are two aspects here: any question of criminality, which is being assessed, and breach of privacy, which is in the domain of the Privacy Commissioner.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, given that the Four Corners revelations follow the recent security breach involving 20 million Visa card accounts in the US and over 200,000 in the Asia-Pacific, has the government held discussions with Australian financial providers concerning the security of Australians’ financial and other details, particularly where such data is provided to subcontracted overseas service providers?

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
talker.role: Minister for Justice and Customs
talker.name: Senator ELLISON

talk.start.para: —The Australian government stands at the forefront with initiatives in relation to credit card fraud and other identity crimes. The Prime Minister has put this on the agenda for COAG, which is meeting in September this year. This is something that requires a whole-of-governments—state, territory and Commonwealth—approach in relation to the protection of identity. In April this year the Attorney-General and I released a Commonwealth strategy on the protection of identity as it relates to Commonwealth agencies and departments. We have also been developing this for some time with the Australian Police Ministers Council in respect of document verification. As I say, we have implemented laws in relation to credit card fraud and other identity related crime. The Australian government is at the forefront in dealing with this issue and will continue to address it as a priority.

talker.name: Hill, Robert (Leader of the Government in the Senate)
Senator Hill

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

debateinfo.title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE: TAKE NOTE OF ANSWERS
debateinfo.type: Questions Without Notice: Take Note of Answers

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts (Senator Coonan) to a question without notice asked by Senator Conroy today relating to Telstra.

speech.para: The minister has demonstrated today that she, like this government, is completely and totally out of touch when it comes to the question of telecommunications. We have here a government which is hell-bent on taking action in complete contrast to the wishes of over two-thirds of the people of this country. We have here a government which is unable to stand up to the management of Telstra which is running riot with a public company. We have to ask ourselves: what would the consequences be of a management like we have now, if the company were fully privatised? We have got into a situation where, according to today’s Financial Review, the management of Telstra is now seeking to blackmail this government—it is set to threaten this government with a capital strike if this government does not do what the management of Telstra wants it to do in regard to the deregulation of telecommunications.

The company is now earning the highest corporate profits this country has ever seen—a figure of some $4½ billion—as a direct result of its price-gouging of domestic consumers. It is a situation in which $125 million has been gouged from the public—for instance, through the massive increases in line rental. Since 2000, we have seen line rentals increase from $11.65 per month to over $30 per month. It is now costing $360 per year just to rent the line and the bit of plastic. That is before you make one single phone call. What would it be like with a fully privatised Telstra?

We now have a situation in which a company is securing profits of $4½ billion. Of that $4½ billion, $2½ billion should come back to the taxpayers. You have to ask yourself: what is the economic logic of a government that seeks to give away those dividends to the public? What is the logic of a government that is seeking to hand money back to the private sector in this way when the needs of this country are so evident and so pressing? How can the government claim that it can buy off part of this parliament and seek to bribe members of this parliament by suggesting that a fund be available for people in regional areas when so many cities in this country are going without services at the moment? You do not have to go to the regional areas to find out just how inadequate Telstra’s services are. You only have to be 90 minutes from the Melbourne CBD, where constituents of mine in the Seymour district—hardly a remote area—say that they cannot get mobile services within one and a half hours of the centre of Melbourne. I am told that you can only get services in parts of the districts around Seymour between 12 pm and 1 pm on a weekday, and you can only do that if you stand on the roof of your ute in a paddock.

I am told that you cannot get mobile services in Canberra, five kilometres from Parliament House, on Hindmarsh Drive and William Hovell Drive. There are blackspots within five minutes of this parliament. We have a similar situation at Bellarine Peninsula just outside Geelong in Victoria where people cannot get mobile services. We have a situation out in Calwell, in Tuggeranong, where, in recently developed areas of this capital city, Telstra cabling will not even support the most rudimentary ADSL services provided. A resident of Calwell has told my office that he had his phone line tested by two internet service providers and both of them said that the line was not up to scratch. We are talking about the capital of Australia, not remote regions. We have the failure of Telstra, despite the enormous profits that it is making, not being able to provide services to this country.

There was a time in this country when Telstra was regarded as one of those fundamental nation-building instruments that the government had at its disposal. We are now being told that, through price gouging and the buying of votes, these fundamental public assets are going to be taken away from the people of this country and given to the private sector for the benefit of the few rather than to build the nation as a whole. We have a situation in which the three amigos in the new Telstra management are now seeking to blackmail this government with a capital strike if this government does not come on board and do what it is told by this new management. We have the Americanisation of telecommunications and we are told that this is good enough for the new-look National Party. How pathetic! (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The contorted, twisted logic we have heard from Senator Carr is simply breathtaking. Senator Carr argues that we ought to not sell Telstra because the services are inadequate and because Australians are not satisfied with the services they receive. He said, ‘Just how inadequate Telstra’s services are is obvious by moving around Australia.’ Senator Carr has quoted from a Newspoll survey which purports to prove that people do not want to sell Telstra, but he neglects to mention that the same poll also canvassed the question of how satisfied Australians were with the services that Telstra provides. What does the poll show? It shows that, in a survey across the whole population, something like 75 per cent of those who were surveyed were either very satisfied or somewhat satisfied with the services provided by Telstra in their local area. Again, a majority of people polled by Newspoll indicated that they found the charges levied by Telstra for their services to be either satisfactory or very satisfactory. Evidence like that demonstrates quite clearly that Australians have noticed that, under this government, there has been a substantive and sustained improvement in the quality of services that Telstra provides. That is not surprising, because this government has assiduously set out to put standards in place that will raise the quality of telecommunications services that Australians can expect to receive.

speech.para: Of course, Labor did none of that. Labor had no plan, no provision of a platform from which services could be built. The fact is that, in Labor’s time of looking after Telstra, we saw services go backwards in many respects. During the 13 years that Labor was in government, there were no requirements on telephone companies to either install a new service or to fix a service or line that had become dysfunctional within any particular time frame. This government has put those standards in place. Under Labor, the most remote customers in Australia could expect to wait up to 27 months for a new service to be installed. Under this government, with the customer service guarantees that have been put in place, no customer has to wait more than 20 working days for a new phone service. Similarly, we have put in place requirements for the repair of lines and other basic standards for provision of services to the community through the universal service obligations. That is a demonstration of why the regulation of those services is important. It is the regulation of those services and the provision of a basic set of standards below which any provider of telecommunications services should not go that are the important features of this debate, not the question of who actually owns the shares in the company.

If we are serious about providing high-quality services to the Australian community, we should do so by setting standards for all providers in the marketplace, not just one of them. Of course, there are a number of those providers out there. Optus, Vodafone, Hutchison and so on are now providing services to the community. We do not own those companies. We should therefore be prepared to regulate that marketplace without having to be in there as the owner of one of those service providers and have the problem of a conflict of interest with both regulating that marketplace and owning one of the key providers within it. The fact is that Australians are broadly satisfied with the services that have been provided by Telstra. To the extent that people are not satisfied, the argument needs to be addressed as to why you would continue with the present ownership arrangements if people are dissatisfied with the services that they receive from Telstra. If those arrangements are in some way connected to the ownership of Telstra then please explain how you need to own Telstra to be able to regulate it. The fact is that you do not, and the lifting of standards that we have achieved— (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —That was a very interesting response because Senator Humphries and no doubt the rest of the Liberal Party are obviously choosing to read only the part they want to read. Senator Humphries makes a great deal of the percentage of people who are satisfied with the service, and completely fails to address the issue that, despite the fact that there has been an increase in satisfaction, there has also been an increase in the number of people who do not want to sell Telstra. This is what the government, for some strange reason, does not seem to get. The Australian public does not want you to sell Telstra.

speech.para: Senator Helen Coonan adopted the same attitude last week when I asked her a question about polling undertaken by the New South Wales Farmers Association. She dismissed that completely. She also dismissed a nationwide poll to which I referred. This poll was in the Canberra Times and was remarkably similar to the Newspoll one which was published in the Australian today. Indeed, the Canberra Times poll goes a bit further, and breaks down by state the level of disapproval of the government for selling Telstra. It was very interesting to note that the disapproval was highest in Queensland, where 79 per cent of those polled disapproved of the government selling Telstra. That has got to be as close to unanimous as you would want. That has got to be a very strong, and increasingly strong, message to the government which they appear determined to ignore. This is apparently on ideological grounds, because the government have been thrashing around trying to find a reason to sell Telstra—because they are regulating, because they want more competition, all these kinds of reasons—but basically they just have an ideological position that they want to sell any asset held in public hands, despite what the people of Australia are telling them.

I think the people of Australia are telling the government that they do not want Telstra sold because there is an increasing understanding that telecommunications are vital to families and to businesses in Australia. This is what, with the improvement of services and the accessing of those services, people are beginning to understand—how much better telecommunications make their life and their business, and how important access to telecommunications is for their lives, for their education and for their business. They do not want control of that telecommunications infrastructure taken out of the hands of the government.

This is something that, up until now anyway, the National Party seemed to be aware of, and that Senator Barnaby Joyce seems to have made great play of in the past. But it now looks like he is also willing to sell out for a slush fund being set up for the National Party. That would indeed be a betrayal of the 79 per cent of Queenslanders who do not want Telstra sold, regardless of the services, if he gave the numbers to the government and voted with them to sell Telstra. It would be a great betrayal of the people who elected the National Party and the Liberal Party to government and to a majority in this house.

It is interesting to see how the government has reacted to the new CEO of Telstra, Mr Trujillo. Every day, Senator Coonan must get up and wish that she had Ziggy Switkowski back as CEO of Telstra, because Sol Trujillo has certainly created a great deal of interest here. The government has been busy fattening up Telstra for sale—by not spending enough on infrastructure, by not spending enough on maintenance and by reducing its work force—to improve the profits of Telstra and make it look good. Then Mr Trujillo comes along, takes over the business and states what is to him blindingly obvious: that in fact not enough has been spent on broadband and other infrastructure by Telstra, that it has been neglected in the past few years and also that Telstra’s profits are likely to diminish with increased competition and with worldwide trends. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —A group of schoolchildren has just left the gallery and they will be asking their teacher, ‘Who was that frightening looking man who spoke about Telstra and seemed angry about Telstra?’ I will tell them who it was. It was Senator Carr, who was so concerned about the sale of Telstra that he made his speech and scurried out of here. This is the same fellow who was so concerned about the Commonwealth Bank and Australian Airlines that he was quite happy for them to be sold off. We did not hear a word from him then.

speech.para: Then he had the gall, in the two minutes he was here, to talk about his regional and rural bona fides. He stopped eating eggs when he found out where they came from, and he has only just discovered where milk comes from. Honestly and truly, how dare Senator Carr come into this chamber and talk about Telstra and telecommunications when he was part of a government which for 13 years did absolutely nothing for telecommunications in this country. Indeed, they left a legacy that I think people have stopped talking about because they do not believe it happened. That legacy was the withdrawal of analog before the 1996 election. With the swipe of a pen they took analog out of the system, without any idea of a replacement. And it was up to this government to do something about it, which we did.

Again, the Labor Party, who did nothing in 13 years of government, have now got the gall to turn around and lecture us. It is a policy-free zone across the other side, and this policy-free zone is lecturing to us about telecommunications in regional and rural Australia. What a gall. You did nothing in 13 years and you have absolutely no idea what you want to do. In fact, I think the only thing you have got going at the moment is—that’s right—$5 billion worth of taxpayers’ money to be spent on now obsolete dial-up internet services. Well, thank you for your contribution to telecommunications in regional and rural Australia, if that is the best you can do after all the time you have had to look at what the deficiencies are!

For the benefit of the Senate and those who are listening, I will just go through what the Allen Consulting Group actually found out about the Howard government’s telecommunications reforms. I will go through those, and you might want to listen. And Senator Carr, instead of coming in here and feigning indignation about Telstra and scurrying off again, should come and listen to this. The Allen Consulting Group found that government reforms have increased the size of the Australian economy by more than $10 billion—$10,000 million; created approximately 26,000 new jobs; and delivered benefits to small businesses of $2.1 billion. As a result, Australian households have been on average $720 better off.

There are now more than 100 telecommunications carriers operating in Australia. What did the Labor Party do? They had this nice cosy little duopoly of Optus and Telstra—or Telecom, as it was—and that is all they did. That was their contribution to telecommunications in this country. There are now more than 16 million mobile phones in operation in Australia, operating on a variety of networks, including Hutchison’s 3G network. The number of broadband subscribers in Australia is now well over one million. In a good sign for competition, almost half of Telstra’s ADSL subscriptions are wholesale services being resold by competitors.

We are happy to have a sensible debate on this, but we are not going to be lectured to by a group of people who simply have no policies to address real issues in regional and rural Australia. This government’s record stands on its own with the money that we have spent, nearly $1 billion, and over 33 new and different programs have gone into regional and rural Australia since 1996—the Liberal and National parties working together to ensure better telecommunications for regional and rural Australia.

talk.start.para: —I do not have a voice of the volume of Senator Ronaldson’s—
—Or Senator Carr’s!

—or Senator Carr’s—but I will certainly speak with as much passion about this issue. I have taken great interest in the responses of Senator Coonan, Senator Humphries and Senator Ronaldson on the issue of the full privatisation of Australia’s national telecommunications carrier, Telstra. I have to say that, having listened carefully to the questions and having read other information that the government have put out justifying their proposal to flog off the rest of Telstra, I am still really puzzled. I am sure my puzzlement will earn me some gratuitous comment from the other side about how naive I am on these matters—and maybe, being a newcomer, I am—but I do not understand why the government want to spend billions of taxpayers’ dollars to prop up Telstra to make it more attractive to private investors when, overwhelmingly, the people of Australia do not want it sold.

speech.para: As Senator Hurley said, there was a survey reported in the Australian newspaper today which said 70 per cent of Australians do not want Telstra sold. But I do not need to refer to a newspaper poll to find out that Australians do not want Telstra sold; I can rely on my own experience. Senator Ronaldson made some gratuitous comment about our bona fides on this side of the house with regard to rural and regional Australia. I can tell you I spent the last 11 years as a union official, and that involved travelling extensively in rural and regional Australia. When the people I was visiting in those areas found out that I had been preselected for the Senate, I can tell you one of the first things they said to me was: ‘What is your position going to be on the sale of Telstra? Because out here in the bush our services are not up to standard. Out here in the bush, we have to beg to have anything comparable with what you’ve got in the city, and we are very frightened about the privatisation of Telstra because we know that what’s going to happen to us is the same as what happened to us’—here in South Australia, they were talking about—‘when the state Liberal government privatised the energy industry in South Australia.’ That is the comparison that the people in rural and regional South Australia are drawing. I can tell you what happened when the energy industry got privatised.

talk.start.para: —I am telling you what happened when another essential service got privatised. That is, the cost to the consumer went up by 20 per cent. Not only did the cost to the consumer go up by 20 per cent but the services that were delivered in the bush went down. They plummeted down, down, down. People in the bush know what privatisation means; it means that they miss out big time.

speech.para: I can tell you that travelling in the bush as a union official was a fraught experience, because you did not need to go too far out of Adelaide before you had no mobile phone coverage. It was rare that you could find somewhere to plug in your laptop and get broadband service. But I only had to be out there a few days. The people I talked to worked in local councils mainly, but often their partners were on farms or they also ran businesses in those rural and regional areas, and they complained bitterly about how they were unable to run their businesses successfully because they just did not have access to basic telecommunications services. So those people in the bush said to me, ‘For God’s sake, don’t support the sale of Telstra, and tell those people on the other side that they shouldn’t support the sale of Telstra either.’
I have spent a bit of time talking to Senator Barnaby Joyce. We are, as you know, in the class of 2004 together and we came into the Senate on 1 July 2005.

talk.start.para: —Honour amongst thieves!

—Senator Ronaldson mentions thieves. We can talk about thieves; we can talk about private telecommunications companies. And, Senator Ronaldson, I have not seen much of Optus or Vodafone out in rural and regional Australia either. I have not seen them setting up offices in Port Augusta, Whyalla or Port Lincoln.

speech.para: I was talking about Senator Joyce’s attitude to the sale of Telstra. I was impressed by the fact that he was going to represent Queenslanders. The Queenslanders put him into power. My mother was a Queenslander. They are great people. They have given us some intriguing and interesting politicians—that is for sure. The fact is that it seems Senator Joyce, unfortunately, is going soft. Somebody mentioned jelly or something before. I hope that has not happened to Senator Joyce and I hope he has not been bought off. (Time expired)
Question agreed to.

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Environment and Heritage (Senator Ian Campbell) to a question without notice asked by Senator Milne today relating to the natural heritage trust fund.

speech.para: I am disturbed at the very clear willingness of the Minister for the Environment and Heritage to manipulate the heritage assessment funding process for political purposes. I particularly want to talk about Recherche Bay in Tasmania. It is clear that the minister was prepared to give an emergency listing to the Kurnell Peninsula in the context of the election campaign when approached by Bruce Baird MP to do so. However, he has not been prepared to give emergency listing to Recherche Bay. Recherche Bay, the northern peninsula in southern Tasmania, is an extraordinarily beautiful area. In fact, it is where the French first landed in 1792-93. It is a highly significant cultural heritage site and landscape. The vista has not changed markedly since the French first landed there. It has been recognised by Emeritus Professor John Mulvaney as a cultural landscape which merits World Heritage listing. Yet we have the minister obviously positioning himself to give the go ahead to logging of the north-east peninsula of Recherche Bay on the basis of values. We are going to see this distortion under the EPBC Act in terms of the World Heritage assessment of Recherche Bay.

We are seeing positioning to give a pocket handkerchief-sized listing to the French garden, another pocket handkerchief-sized listing to the observatory and the go ahead to log the rest of it, when the value of that peninsula in a cultural sense relates to the whole landscape. The French and the Indigenous people moved right across that magnificent landscape. It is where the first recording was made of a Tasmanian Aboriginal language. It is also the place of the first positive encounter between Europeans and the Tasmanian Indigenous people. It should be listed. I believe we will see quite a duplicitous process with the minister having two bob each way. He was positioning himself for that today: on the one hand, saying that the logging can go ahead and, on the other, trying to mislead people into thinking that the heritage values have been protected if two tiny areas are protected.

It is a cultural landscape and this will be a real test for this new Australian Heritage Council. Today, we heard the minister, firstly, mislead the Senate in relation to the Bradman projects and, secondly, give an example of political manipulation whereby the Cootamundra Shire Council did not even put in a funding application, yet it got $50,000. What about all those people around Australia who have put in funding applications and did not get them? The Prime Minister’s office clearly was involved in that decision. I note the minister ducked that part of the question as to the extent to which the Prime Minister was involved not only in the Bradman cricket walk but also in terms of the Recherche Bay project and its listing as a matter of cultural heritage.

When I was in Paris I met with people in the natural history museum and in several academic institutions and there is huge interest from the French side in protecting this area. There is an enormous amount of willingness to set up cultural collaborative projects with Australia and French institutions, including the academy of science in Paris. They recognise how critical it is. Some of the earliest samples of the Eucalyptus globulus, which is Tasmania’s floral emblem, can be found in the natural history museum in Paris. It was taken there by de Labillardiere, the botanist on the expedition.

If the minister is prepared to list the place where Captain Cook landed then this is equally important, if not more important, because of its importance to Tasmania’s Indigenous community and to the whole community in terms of reconciliation. It would acknowledge to the world that we recognise that a positive encounter with Indigenous people is something that should be on the Australian natural heritage list. Recherche Bay should be there. The minister needs to explain why it is not there and, if he just goes with a pocket handkerchief size, why he is prepared to repudiate the advice of Emeritus Professor Mulvaney, one of the most highly respected heritage authorities in this country.
Question agreed to.

talker.name: Boswell, Sen Ron
talker.role: Leader of The Nationals in the Senate
talker.name: Senator BOSWELL

talk.start.para: —by leave—In my speech on ethanol in the matters of public interest debate last Wednesday, I attributed two quotes to a Mr Peter Harris. They should in fact have been attributed to the Australian Financial Review editorial on 27 July 2005. The first quote was:

quote.para: The only real beneficiary would be that chastened donor to the conservative parties, Dick Honan and his Manildra Group.

speech.para: The second quote was:
