Some members on the other side have raised the issue of speaking up when a foreigner in the personage of President Bush was speaking to a joint meeting of the chambers. In the chamber I got up, from the position to which I had been elected, and spoke up for my constituents. Let me say that since that day nothing has brought a response more strongly and more positively to me everywhere I go in this nation from Australian citizens who say, ‘Senator Brown, you stood up for me when you stood up and spoke across the chamber to President Bush.’

talk.start.para: —What is more, that is why the Greens vote is growing, Senator, and I address that to the senator from the other side who is interjecting against the rules—that is, Senator Abetz. Let me add that we have a duty to speak out, wherever the Senate might be, on behalf of our constituents. So we have two rulings with which I disagreed. In the case of saying ‘blackmail’ in this chamber, we had a vote. And in the case of the matter in the other place, the indiscretion of the Speaker of the day was to not take a division, although it was called for, and he made a ruling which he had no right to make. I believe that in the future, when constitutional historians investigate that, they will find that he, in his decision not to allow Senator Nettle and me to attend the consequent day’s sitting, in fact acted illegally and against the Constitution.

speech.para: That aside, we are dealing here with an obscene gesture. Mr President, you might not think it is obscene, but I do not believe that you are being true to your own heart in this. You have spoken up and made your decision. You might not believe that it is obscene, but I ask you: if that is not, what is? If that is not obscene, where do you draw the line? Of course, you are not going to give an answer to the Senate on that. Your ruling was wrong. It was politically biased. It has the presage—and we must all fear this—of more to come. It was a derogation of your duty in the chair to independently defend this chamber against obscene behaviour, which is a contempt. You did not do that. You should have revised your ruling, but in the lack of a revision of your ruling you are wrong, and I support the motion.

talker.name: Evans, Sen Chris
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate
talker.name: Senator CHRIS EVANS

talk.start.para: —I want to make a few short remarks in this debate. It has been a bit of a therapy session so far. First of all we had Senator Bartlett discussing his incident and then Senator Brown discussing his. I just want to stick to the topic at hand.
—Only because it was raised.

—I know, but we have to get a grip of ourselves and concentrate on the issue at hand, which is: are we dissenting from the President’s ruling? On behalf of the Labor Party I indicate that we will not be supporting the dissent motion. Senator Allison, I indicated on the day that I did not think that it was the way to go. Labor still take that view. Equally, the ruling by the President not to refer the matter to the Privileges Committee is sound. In my view, the matter should have been treated a little more seriously than it was, but we agree with the ruling on the two key points. Firstly, should the President’s ruling be dissented from? Labor will vote no because I do not think the case has been made that a serious issue of dissent should be entertained. And, secondly, the ruling on the reference to the Privileges Committee is also fairly sound.

speech.para: I do consider this to be a very unsavoury incident. It is a blight on the reputation of the Senate, and I treat it very seriously. We all make mistakes. Senator McGauran clearly made one. His biggest mistake, though, was his failure then to come into the chamber and apologise properly. He showed a lack of courage and a lack of good manners. Again, he is not in here today. There was a rumour that he was going to have the courage to front up today, but he has gone missing in action. I think that is his greatest failure. We all make blues. We have all done things we are not terribly proud of. The hardest but best thing is to front up and apologise straightaway and take responsibility for your actions. Senator McGauran did not do that. He gave a very half-hearted statement which begrudgingly acknowledged that he might have offended some people. He did offend people, and his behaviour did bring shame on him and on the Senate. I think that is true. As I said, the biggest thing that stands against Senator McGauran is his failure to make a proper apology to the Senate.

I think it is a metaphor for the government’s attitude to the Senate that on that day Senator McGauran thought that giving the Senate the finger was the appropriate way for a government senator to behave. It was reinforced, I understand, by Senator Heffernan, who attended the Greens press conference and gave them the finger as a reinforcement of the government’s attitude on these matters. I take that only from what I have read in the papers; I have no personal knowledge of it. If that is not true, I will be happy to correct the record. But that is what has been widely reported in the press by a number of sources. Again, it is a metaphor for the government’s attitude to the Senate, its control in the Senate chamber, its view about its total control, and its arrogance and propensity to abuse that power.

But that is not a reason for us to disagree with the President’s ruling. I regard that as a very serious step. Senator Bartlett alluded to the fact that it did not mean this and it did not mean that. Any President who has a dissent from his ruling carried successfully by the chamber would have to examine his position; that is certainly my view. It would be a statement that we would take very seriously. I am not saying that we would rule out doing that on an occasion. I make it very clear that Labor would do that if they thought there was a fundamental wrong in a ruling by the President or there had been partisan bias shown in such a ruling. It is a step that we would take very seriously. As I said, I do not think that is at all justified on this occasion.

To be honest, I think we ought to move on. A debate in this chamber about whether something is ‘unseemly’ or ‘unparliamentary’ does not excite me. I do not think it excites many others in Australia. I think Australians just want to see better behaviour from their parliamentarians. They want to see us moving on with their interests. Things like climate change, Senator Brown, are important issues that the Senate ought to be dealing with in a respectful way while treating other senators with respect. I do not think that Australian citizens are interested in whether this was ‘unseemly’ or ‘unparliamentary’. I do not think a lot hinges on it. I accept the President’s ruling and judgment on those things.

I think the Australian people have made their judgment about the behaviour. They have seen the footage, the photo and the reaction. The Prime Minister on the weekend made it clear that he had read the wind as well and was not supportive of Senator McGauran’s actions. I think it is a very poor sign that the senator still has not provided a proper apology. But, obviously, Mr Howard and Mr Costello were not prepared to defend his position. I think they know that the Australian people have made their judgment about such behaviour as well.

I also think some of the hyperbole about this matter has gotten a bit carried away. Senator Bartlett’s point on that front was reasonable. But I do not agree with some of those journalists who then used that as an excuse to say that it was all a bit too much that there was a response in the Senate. I do not think that is right either. I think it is appropriate that the Senate deal with it seriously. Whilst some of the contributions might have fallen into hyperbole, the bottom line is that that behaviour towards other senators is not appropriate.

It ought not to have happened. But, having happened, the senator ought to have made an unreserved apology. I think everyone in the Senate would accept that. I do not think that any senator would argue differently. Quite frankly, that would have been the end of the matter on the day. The fact that it was not done is something that Senator McGauran will have to live with. But I do think the government should have treated the issue more seriously. I think the failure of the government to treat the issue more seriously is a reflection on it and on its attitude now to the Senate and accountability.

I am much more concerned, Mr President, as I have expressed to you previously, about your ruling on question time allocation than I am on this particular ruling. That is one ruling I will be pursuing with you and will not be giving up on, because that is a fundamental question about accountability and the role of this chamber in holding the government to account. So I am much more concerned about that. I am much more concerned about whether or not the Senate Employment, Workplace Relations and Education Legislation Committee will have a proper ability to examine the industrial relations legislation. Minister Andrews announced an inquiry yesterday and I see that the Prime Minister has repudiated that already. That is an issue of much more concern to me. I am much more concerned about keeping the government accountable and not allowing it to use the Senate in an arrogant fashion.

Mr President, we will not be supporting the motion to dissent from your ruling. I understand why Senator Allison initiated the motion at the time, and I am not critical of that, but on balance we will not support it. I think your ruling on the privileges matter is appropriate. As I said, on balance, the government should have treated the matter more seriously, but I do not think that anything you have done should be disputed in this chamber. I think it is a reasonable conclusion to draw and a reasonable judgment. Labor will be supporting your ruling.

talker.name: Allison, Sen Lyn
talker.role: Leader of the Australian Democrats
talker.name: Senator ALLISON

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I want to indicate first of all that there was no intention on my part to suggest that a motion which would dissent from your ruling had other connotations, such as a lack of confidence in you as President or any indication that you should stand down. That is certainly not the case. As far as I can see from the standing orders—and somebody might correct me—I do not see anything in there that would imply that as an objective.

speech.para: The main reason for this motion was that I could not agree with you that conduct that was ‘unseemly’ on the part of Senator McGauran could also be parliamentary. You said it was not unparliamentary, which suggests that it was parliamentary. I could not imagine this place with us all going about making gestures to one another which are at the very least indecent if not obscene. I would argue that the intention behind that gesture was certainly obscene. But people are offended in various degrees by it.

The problem, though, is that in the past you have ruled a lot of things in this chamber, mostly words that are spoken, to be unparliamentary and you have insisted that they be withdrawn. What I cannot see is any reason why a gesture could not also be withdrawn. Instead of that, you agreed to investigate it. We had a grudging apology from Senator McGauran, which I think satisfied nobody in this chamber. Nobody truly felt that this apology being made was heartfelt or truly an apology at all. That is why we are in this difficult situation.

I went to the dictionary as well, Senator Brown. ‘Unseemly’ has two definitions—that is, ‘unbecoming’ and ‘indecent’—according to the Oxford English Dictionary. Again, I would say that it cannot be indecent and parliamentary. The judgment needs to be made on the basis of what is reasonable and appropriate behaviour in this place and how it is judged by the general public. As was observed at the time, there were children in the gallery. I am sure that children have seen this gesture before. But the point is how we as leaders in this country wish to be seen by the general public and whether we wish to present an example of appropriate behaviour to both adults and young people who might come to see the work that we do. It is hardly surprising that people hold politicians and parliamentarians in low regard. They observe question time, and now most of the country knows that at least one senator in this place has made a gesture which was, I would argue, intended to be obscene or at least indecent.

It is clear that this motion is not going to get support in the chamber. It is also clear that Senator McGauran does not intend to give an apology which would satisfy us that he meant it. It is a sad reflection on this place that we can perhaps look forward to even more of what I would regard as unparliamentary behaviour on the basis that it is unseemly but somehow not something else. It is disappointing that we are in this situation, but in many ways I think that if that action is not taken at the time the event happened we are dredging over old coals and people become entrenched in positions. I think that is what has happened here. But I would urge, Mr President, that in the future such behaviour is ruled by you to be unparliamentary, because to do otherwise is simply not appropriate or acceptable.

talker.name: Boswell, Sen Ron
talker.role: Leader of The Nationals in the Senate
talker.name: Senator BOSWELL

talk.start.para: —Mr President, you have ruled that Senator McGauran’s gesture was unseemly but was by no means a terrible act. I have been here for 23 years, and I have seen a lot of indiscretions in this place. I have seen them from all sides of parliament on many occasions, and I have said, ‘Let them go through to the keeper.’ Senator McGauran has apologised. He has certainly apologised in the media, on John Laws’s program, on channel 9 and in this parliament. I know that Senator McGauran regrets what he did. It was on the spur of the moment, when we do a lot of things. As Senator Evans has said, I think all of us do things that we regret. I have seen Labor Party members come in here—and I will not mentioned their names, because they were good people—and I have seen Democrats, Greens and probably National Party members and Liberals come in here and commit indiscretions. But we have to live in this place. We are here for much of the year, and we have to accept that if we put the spotlight on every indiscretion that happens we are only reflecting on what is happening here, and that leaves a bad image out in the general community.

speech.para: I accept Senator Evans’s discussion, and he has said that he will not be supporting a dissent motion on the President’s ruling. I really do regret, Senator Allison, that you are moving this motion. I find it very hard to accept, because when one of your members committed an indiscretion—

talk.start.para: —It was a lot worse.

—I do not want to go into who is worse than whom and who does what, but when he did it this side of the House decided: ‘Let it go through to the keeper. We are not going to pursue it or take it up.’ Yet you come in here and cry holier than thou.
—Are you talking about mine?
—I am not talking about—
—Yeah, nobody pursued me.

—I certainly did not pursue you, and I would not pursue anyone, because I know that these things happen—they happen in life, and they are going to continue to happen here when we are under pressure, and there was a certain amount of pressure counting the vote. There is no excuse for the action at all, but these things do happen. So I regret that you have pursued this, Senator Allison. It is unfitting of you. You are leading a party that has in it a person who did commit an indiscretion, and now you get up here and call everyone black. It is an instance of the pot calling the kettle black, and I cannot believe that you have done it. I thought you had more brains than to get up here and lead a debate on someone else’s indiscretion when a member of your party has really offended.

speech.para: It is time that we got on with the more important issues. Senator McGauran has apologised. He is in here at the moment. I do not think it serves any other purpose to pursue this. I propose that we get on with the real issues that are affecting the Senate and close this matter down. Senator Brown has got his moment of glory. To my way of thinking, he is a populist from the Left—a Pauline Hanson from the Left, not from the Right. Divide and get your lousy five per cent of the vote.
Debate interrupted.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 6.50 pm, the Senate will proceed to the consideration of government documents.
—I move:

motion.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

speech.para: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

speech.para: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

speech.para: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

talk.start.para: —Order! There being no further consideration of government documents, I propose the question:

motion.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —Yesterday, as everybody in this place and millions and millions of Australians know, was the observation of the 60th anniversary of VP Day. For a number of reasons, I was unfortunately unable to attend VP Day observations, but I do want to make some remarks in the chamber tonight. I think it is appropriate, in reflecting on the nature of this particular commemoration, to quote the words of WS Kent Hughes from the dedication in his work Slaves of the Samurai. He wrote: ‘Dedicated to my comrades who still live and will live even though they are not alive.’ For anyone who has cast an eye over Slaves of the Samurai, the creation, but most particularly the preservation, of his verses is fascinating in itself. The pictures in the work by Major-General De Fremery, similarly so, but I find that dedication particularly compelling. Not everybody would choose to reflect on an occasion such as VP Day with poetry but, for many reasons, I have chosen to do so. I grew up in a World War II veteran’s family. I was particularly encouraged to pursue my own interest in the arts by my father—a veteran of World War II. So the 60th anniversary of VP Day particularly resonates for me.

speech.para: On 15 August 1945 the war had finally reached its end and, in very simple terms, the then Prime Minister began his announcement with the words: ‘Fellow citizens, the war is over.’ It was a time of elation for all Australians but also a time of sadness for the many lives lost. But, through it all, the Australian spirit shone, and we have been repeatedly reminded of this in recent days, with the iconic images of Australians dancing in the streets and celebrating the freedom that had been defended at such great cost.

Yesterday I shared my mother’s reminiscences of VP Day. She was at school on VP Day—in fact, the same school that I attended. The part of the school which in my day we called ‘the field’ in her day was filled with trenches where they practised for eventualities that hopefully would never come. On this anniversary of VP Day, she reminisced about being allowed out of school late morning, making her way with hundreds of other girls to Strathfield Station in Sydney’s inner west and fighting the crowds at the station. When the trains from the city finally arrived, they were absolutely jam-packed—you could not get on the trains—but somehow, for some reason, the people of Sydney made way for these groups of schoolgirls dressed in the navy blue uniforms so that they could go home to their families to celebrate the end of World War II.

Sixty years later those images still resonate with us. Now, when we understand that freedom is something to be won and to be cherished, those images remind us in many ways of a time when our way of life was not so assured. I think with that comes a great sense of humility and gratitude for the thousands of Australians who perished to defend their nation, our people and our way of life. More than 900,000 Australian men and women enlisted in the armed forces between 1939 and 1945 from a population of barely seven million. Of that figure, 550,000 service men and women served outside Australia in one of the services during the war. That was one in 12 people of the total population—and my father was one of those.

Twenty-seven men from the small New South Wales village of Burrawang enlisted for World War II, but my father had already moved to Sydney so was recorded as enlisted from Undercliff. The Sydney Sun on the day of his enlistment carried a pictorial story sporting my then—and in fact always—very handsome father moving from civilian to private in the space of one day. It is a news clipping which I of course cherish. The list of surnames of those who enrolled from the village of Burrawang is a history of that small community and, in many ways, the history of my family—names that I remember my father speaking of on many occasions.

My father’s service record has him enlisting on 9 March 1941 and being discharged on 14 March 1946—a very long time in a young life to spend in the service of your nation—with a total effective service period of 1,831 days, which included active service in Australia for 1,292 days and outside Australia for 327 days. He left the Army as a lieutenant. That time in the Second AIF changed my father’s life—as it did for so many Australians. His service and his pride had an extraordinary impact on my life and our upbringing.

Australia had earned the respect of the world for the actions of our troops in various theatres of war, and that was solidly and effectively reinforced by World War II. Australia’s identity of mateship—many would say—of bravery and determination was forged even more strongly by the events of World War II. Victory in the Pacific was extraordinarily hard won.

In discussing Australia’s commemoration of VP Day, I think it would be remiss to not make reference to the horrendous weapons that did indeed bring the world to a standstill and force the surrender of Japan. I am of course referring to the atomic bombs dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki on 6 and 9 August 1945. We all listened with interest to the reminiscences and the stories of those experiences in recent weeks as well. I have visited the memorial and the park in Hiroshima. It is an extraordinarily compelling and confronting experience, particularly for one who grew up in an Australian World War II veteran’s family with a very interesting perspective of our engagement against the Japanese. It is one of the most impressive memorials I have ever seen. Its commemoration is, I think, a very important part of the modern world.

Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi has used the 60th anniversary of the bombings of Nagasaki and Hiroshima and the commemoration of VP Day to urge all nations to abandon their nuclear weapons program. The nuclear non-proliferation program is really one of the most important projects of the 21st century and one that Australia pursues with great energy and seriousness in tackling what is an enormous challenge for us in this century. This is so particularly in light of the changes in the interaction between nations and the intervention of non-state players in those interactions. This makes for a very different landscape from what was perhaps 60 years ago a more predictable environment in terms of battle and confrontation, upon which to draw a picture for the future of conflict and, in fact, the prevention of conflict.

I hope that I am forgiven by the Senate for personalising my observations about VP Day, but when we come to this place we come with the influence of our families and their histories and we bring the experiences that they visited upon us. I began by making reference to WS Kent Hughes and his extraordinarily evocative writings in Slaves of the Samurai and how very compelling it is to read those. But there are many other war poets who have made an extraordinary contribution throughout not just Australia’s history but also internationally in terms of the recording of experience, of horror in many cases, of humour in so many Australian cases and of emotion generally about war.

There is a wonderful anthology of poetry of the Australian Army which contains many interesting reminiscences of the south-west Pacific area, Australia, Papua New Guinea, Bougainville and Borneo from 1942 to 1945. Some of the poets’ work contained therein bring a wry smile, some are positively horrific and terrifying and some are just so emotionally draining that they are hard to read at length. I did want to make another brief reference to a poem called Fuzzy Wuzzy Angels which was dedicated to Sapper Victor Cook from the Royal Australian Engineers. The last few lines sum up some of the things that my father often said about fighting in Papua New Guinea. It says:

quote.para: May the Mothers in Australia,
When they offer up a prayer,
Mention those impromptu Angels,
With the Fuzzy Wuzzy hair.

speech.para: An amusing observation about the saving of so many of our soldiers by so many dedicated members in Papua New Guinea at the time, and one I think that it is entirely appropriate to conclude upon this evening.

talk.start.para: —I rise this evening to address issues affecting recruiting within the Australian defence forces. This matter has risen to some prominence as the result of a government proposal put about in the press late last week. That proposal was to extend the role of women in the Australian Defence Force and it has been accompanied by the release of ASPI’s analysis of the Defence budget for the financial year of 2005-06. That analysis shows that Australia’s defence capacity is severely handicapped by personnel shortages across the board.

speech.para: This discussion is not just about failed recruiting campaigns of latter years but also about continuing high attrition rates and skills shortages. The single rationale offered is that defence recruiting must compete in the labour market with general industry. That is a statement of the obvious, of course. Moreover, the demand is not just for infantry and general support numbers, the demand is for people who can play a role in a new hi-tech environment and employment area. A number of solutions have been canvassed recently. Some, indeed, are worth considering, but not all, of course. The member for Mackellar last weekend, for example, suggested that the recruitment age should be reduced from the age of 18 to 14. Perhaps she has been watching too much Hornblower. It is a wonder she did not suggest the restoration of press gangs. They were a marvellously efficient recruiting technique on British wharves. They swept up all of the idlers in society and got them out of the community eye. It would be an immediate social solution of great appeal to the honourable member, no doubt, and perhaps those on Work for the Dole might be pressed as well. In any event, it is good, immediately actionable, highly appealable and great conservative stuff right out of Mrs Thatcher’s textbook.

A more sensible suggestion has been the extension of the role of women in the Australian Defence Force. I think most agree that there is some scope here for extension, improvement and change. Some women’s groups—most wisely, I think—saw the debate on women in combat as a shield covering labour and skills shortages both in the defence forces and our wider community. The continuing concern is that women may not be particularly suited for frontline fighting roles. It seems—and there was a press report today to that effect—that mixing genders in combat has been problematic wherever attempted. Regardless of the range of views, there does seem to be some consensus emerging in Australia that we are not prepared to see this happen at this stage or in this instance—support roles yes, not the actual combat role, not the hand-to-hand stuff. However, I think the caveat needs to be entered that this development must be analysed over the longer term. It is interesting when you go back and look at the press in the late 30s, early 40s and right through the years of World War II, to note that a similar debate was held when manpower—or person power—was very short. That though was a watershed issue of women in the work force, not for women in warfare. No doubt this evolution will continue but it is not the sole answer.

The causes of ADF recruitment problems are much deeper than that, so we should turn to the ASPI figures. ADF numbers, after falling in the early nineties, have since been relatively static. Since 2000 the total ADF strength has wavered between 50,000 and 52,000. The trend, though, is flat, with a strong likelihood that targets will continue to fail to be reached. Over the last nine years targets have been reached, on average, by only 86 per cent. In fact, over the last nine years they have fallen from 96 per cent. Retention rates are also considered to be problematic. Over the last nine years these have wavered between 10 per cent at best and 14 per cent at worst. This does seem wasteful, but I am advised that it is also a dynamic feature of service, especially in lower, non-commissioned ranks. There, as I understand it, the average length of service is about four to five years. This makes recruitment and training quite expensive. Forty-one per cent of the entire defence budget is spent on personnel—that is, $6.7 billion this year. In the last five years alone, over $500 million has been spent on recruitment and retention measures.

One asks: what is the reason for these recruitment shortfalls? The Defence and ASPI view is that competition in the labour market is at present very tight. But that does not wash, really, because the problem has been with us for almost a decade. Just look at the figures published by ASPI in more recent times. Some also say it is about pay and conditions, but that has always been the case. In fact, the package of pay and conditions, including health care, housing and superannuation, is very attractive for new recruits. The recent attitudes survey does not show this to be an issue. Indeed, I can say that in the past four years my office has not received one complaint in writing or over the phone about the level of pay or allowances within the Australian defence forces. I concluded from that that the issue did not cause disharmony or dispute within the ADF.

I am informed that the trends in those surveys over the last five years are in fact statistically positive on many indicators. But there can be no doubt that life in the services is very different from that of the general population. It is very disruptive. Families tire of frequent shifts around the country. Partners are understandably having greater trouble coping when enlisted members are absent for long periods of duty. Given the increased tempo of overseas deployments, that disruption is getting worse and, one suggests, is likely to continue to get worse.

Old hands would say: ‘So what? What’s new? We managed; why can’t they? Get used to it.’ The answer is of course that partners and families today see other models and other career choices. Naturally, their own career aspirations have become stronger. Community values and expectations are changing, but defence life, unfortunately, as much as people like to talk about it, does not seem to be switching to new models. We know it is a genuine matter for concern, and attempts are being made to minimise disruption, but, by God, it is slow going. We can only hope that the increasing concentration of bases closer to large urban areas will help. The provision of employment choices for partners is very important. Life in the military should not be a disqualification.

Looking more broadly, people’s choices of lifestyle these days are far greater than they have ever been. Think about the 20th century: World War I, the Great Depression, World War II, Korea and, overlaying the last 70 years, the Cold War. In that century, a career in defence loomed as a significant option. Many in the past have seen service as a means of getting some skills and developing career options. That was the case especially when those skills were transferable to the general labour market. Some are speculating publicly now that tertiary education might be offered as recruitment bait more widely than is currently the case. But already traineeships in avionics, electronics, communications and many other areas of skill demand are available in the defence forces. All are transferable to the general labour market. The traditional loss of trained RAAF pilots to civil aviation is a high-profile phenomenon. Perhaps this is more of a symptom of the failure of industry to commit to training. Skills poaching is not a new phenomenon. There is more to be said on this matter, and I will speak on it at another time.

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to raise an issue that I am probably starting to sound like a broken record on, and that is genetic privacy and genetic discrimination in Australia. The reason I raise this issue tonight is twofold: firstly, this is National Science Week, so it is fitting within that context; and, secondly, as some honourable senators would be aware, today some aspects of a report on genetic privacy and discrimination were released. They included a world first survey by the Centre for Genetics Education on Australian attitudes to predictive genetic testing. The results of that study, among others, reveal that a number of Australians are very wary and quite suspicious of the use of genetic tests because they think they may be used for nefarious purposes.

speech.para: I would suggest that, despite the dazzling and wonderful potential of genetics and genetic technology—something that I rave about in this place on many occasions—there are good reasons for Australians to be quite wary of, or at least have some reservations about, the use of genetic tests, simply because we still do not have national legislation in which genetic privacy is specifically protected. Nor do we have legislation on a national level that specifically outlaws genetic discrimination. The reality is that information gleaned from genetic tests has been used in this country to deny people access to employment and insurance.

This is an issue that I talked about many years ago in this place. In fact, I said that, like the United States, Australia would have to confront the issue of genetic discrimination. I introduced a private senator’s bill in 1998, based on some work I had looked at in the United States, where they have confronted these issues, as they have in Europe and other places. The bill went to a committee, which produced one of the most comprehensive reports I have seen in this place. But the legislation was not supported by either major party. There were some good reasons for that. It was partly because the bill was very much focused on an international—and particularly American—model. Nonetheless, major parties in this place did not believe that we needed stand-alone legislation to deal with genetic privacy and nondiscrimination. I still think we could do with it, but at a minimum I would like to see some changes made to law. Amendments could be made to the Privacy Act. In the past I have tried to do that but have failed because at the end of the day the ALP has not supported my amendments, after supporting them on at least one prior occasion. Amendments could also be made to disability discrimination law, as has been recommended to this place by external bodies.

I have been raising this issue for a long time. Since 1998 we have seen recorded cases of genetic discrimination in Australia and it is about time the government acted on this issue. There is no reason for the government not to act when they have seen not only surveys and studies, such as today’s report, but also the overwhelming evidence from researchers and academics on this topic—most importantly, the ALRC report that was produced in March 2003. The ALRC and AHEC report—a two-volume report, one volume of which is on my desk in front of me now—contains the most comprehensive research into genetic privacy and the sort of related issue of genetic discrimination. It is one of the best research tools in the world, so much so that this report is discussed in other parliaments and certainly in other jurisdictions around the world. It has been held up as a world-class body of evidence that is being used to craft and draft laws in other places, such as in the United Kingdom, where they have looked at this report. The ALRC and Australians should be justifiably proud of that work.

I do not understand why the government has had the ALRC 96 report since March 2003 yet has not acted on the report or its recommendations. They are great recommendations; they are not partisan and they are worth acting on. I asked Senator Ellison about this in recent times when we had a debate on one of the family law bills that dealt with the vexed issue of parentage testing—another area covered by the ALRC report. My attempts on that occasion to get an amendment passed, or at least get the report’s recommendations looked at and implemented, once again failed. Nonetheless, I asked Senator Ellison: when will the government respond to this report? His response was:

quote.para: I can say that the government hope to finalise their response to the report shortly.

speech.para: That was earlier this year during the Family Law Amendment Bill debate. Tonight, from a nonpartisan perspective, I genuinely urge—because this issue is so important and because people’s lives are at stake—the government to act, even if it is only with minimal changes to law. It is time for Australia to outlaw genetic discrimination and to protect genetic privacy. It is high time it was done.

We know that advances in gene technology and the increasingly widespread use of genetic testing confirm that the kind of legislation that I am talking about is urgently needed. Despite my bill, the ALRC report, a Senate inquiry and a recent Senate inquiry that I initiated into the Privacy Act, laws governing genetics remain a mishmash of legislations, regulations, codes of conduct, industry self-regulations, activities and reports by public sector agencies and regulators. Genetic testing continues unabated with scant regulation and, while it is an exciting area with much potential to improve our lives, it must be regulated to ensure that people’s privacy is protected.

A comprehensive national network of laws, ethical practices and regulation is long overdue. Many reports of genetic discrimination come from the use of tests in the insurance industry. Although the industry cannot request applicants to take genetic tests when applying for insurance, results from prior tests can be disclosed. For example, a man with a history of bowel cancer refused to be genetically tested for this condition because he realised that doing so could jeopardise his insurance coverage. So he actually endangered his life and prevented the chances of early diagnosis—something that is important—in order to maintain his insurance coverage. We know that some Australian women have been discouraged from taking the test for the breast cancer gene because they are worried about the impact on their insurance. Remember that at the heart of all this is the fact that genetic tests are predictive; they are not certain, they are not definite. If you test positive for a particular gene or condition, there is the potential that you could develop a certain disease or condition; it does not mean you are going to. That is one very real reason that people face discrimination and they do so unfairly.

Genetic testing in the insurance industry is self-regulated. The members in that industry follow a policy drafted by the Insurance and Financial Services Association. I have had dealings with them and in the past we have worked very well to come up with something in this area, because the insurance companies realised early that they would be the subject of attack if they did not act in this area. Although the policy seeks to protect applicants’ genetic privacy and ensure test results are provided voluntarily, past surveys and anecdotal evidence do suggest that applicants with unfavourable tests have been denied insurance or have been granted insurance with higher premiums. This agreement lapses on 5 December this year and I urge the industry to extend that agreement until we have effective laws in place.

An earlier survey by one of the leading researchers in this area and one of the authors of the research mentioned today, Dr Kristine Barlow-Stewart of the New South Wales Centre for Genetics Education, found that 30 per cent of people affected by genetic disorders had experienced some form of discrimination—that is, nearly one-third of people with a genetic condition had experienced genetic discrimination. Two brothers, whose father committed suicide after his genetic test revealed Huntington’s disease, encountered discrimination in buying insurance. Both were tested for the Huntington’s genes. One yielded a positive result and he was refused insurance altogether. The other brother, whose result indicated no presence of the genes for the disease, was already paying a higher premium because of the family’s history of the disease. His request that his premiums be reassessed was initially rejected. Of most concern are people who have been screened and showed a probability or certainty of developing a disease in the future but were presently healthy and were either denied insurance or granted it but with higher premiums.

Our genetic privacy is under threat from a number of areas, but primarily it is under threat from ineffectual laws. Genetic information produced as a result of testing is vaguely included in the Privacy Act 1988 but it is considered part of ‘personal information’. That is not good enough. We know that. The act has to specifically recognise ‘genetic information’. As the ALRC recognised in Essentially yours, genetic samples used in tests, even if they identify a person, are not covered by the act. And although it may be considered theft, taking samples of other people’s DNA without their consent is not currently a criminal offence. Mr Acting Deputy President, I have run out of time, but you can be assured that I will be raising this issue again in the Senate before too long.

talk.start.para: —I listened very carefully to Senator Stott Despoja’s speech, the contents of which certainly are most deserving of greater consideration.

speech.para: As senators know, I take a very close interest in the ABC, not least because it has a vital role to play as our national broadcaster. It is a service that is very heavily relied on in rural and regional Queensland in particular. Most of what the ABC does is of a very high standard, but it lets itself down by continuing displays of bias, most particularly in news and current affairs, much of which, it would seem, is caused by confusing and inconsistent management. It is on this theme that I wish to speak tonight.

The ABC news boss, John Cameron, has recognised the potential for allegations or realities of bias to damage the ABC in a series of memos. ‘We leave ourselves open to reasonable criticism,’ he warned in one such memo. In a memo in March 2003 Mr Cameron said, ‘Do not use anything that could be construed as emotional language or editorialisation.’

The issue is also covered in ABC editorial policies and in its news division style guide, where it states the following: ‘The familiarity bred by the use of first names when addressing or referring to certain people often evokes a sense of ABC sympathy for the cause.’ News and current affairs staff were banned from referring to ‘our troops in Iraq’ because the ABC does not own them and therefore they are not ‘ours’ as far as the ABC is concerned. Staff were warned about the consequences of breaching the rules. ‘The rules are not optional; they are mandatory,’ wrote Mr Cameron. The memo went on to say, ‘Continued transgressions will lead to formal documentation which in turn can have a major impact on career progression and eventually ongoing employment status.’ Mr Cameron issued the memo banning the use of ‘our’ in March 2003. Between then and now I have found more than 400 examples of breaches of this rule, including ‘our Anzacs’, ‘our Vietnam soldiers’, ‘our diggers at Gallipoli’, ‘our forensic police in Bali’ and ‘our Australian Federal Police helping in London’. There were 400 ‘ours’ in two years and the only time Mr Cameron did anything about it was when someone said ‘our troops in Iraq’.

Despite the warnings about disciplinary action, Quentin Dempster from Stateline New South Wales breached the rule 65 times and he is still on air. There were no memos from Mr Cameron and no action against staff, because the breaches did not involve the Iraq war. Just as Mr Cameron predicted, the ABC has created an unfavourable impression—that is, that the ABC opposes Australian involvement in the Iraq war. Mr Cameron was quite right to point out to staff that referring to some people by their first name creates an impression that the ABC sympathises with that person or their cause. Since that memo, David Hicks has become ‘David’ on The World Today with Nance Haxton, Cornelia Rau has become just ‘Cornelia’ on the 7.30 Report, and Vivian Alvarez Solon became ‘Vivian’ six times in one report by Margot O’Neill on Lateline. In Western Australia, Stateline interviewed a Liberal Party candidate and an ALP candidate. The Liberal was ‘Dean Solly’ but the ALP man, Jay Radisich, became simply ‘Jay’. Kim Beazley became ‘Kim’ on Insiders. John Howard became ‘Howard’ with Kerry O’Brien on the 7.30 Report, while Kim Beazley became ‘Kim’. So the ABC has allowed itself to do exactly what Mr Cameron warned against: create a distinct impression that it sides with David Hicks, the Labor Party and the cause celebre of immigration activists.

In a further example of antigovernment and pro-Labor bias, the ABC breached its rule on disclosure on The World Today on 27 May this year. In a story about the union campaign against government workplace relations reforms, the reporter, Liz Foschia, introduced one Fran Tierney as a community worker in the not-for-profit sector. Fran Tierney is in fact a trade union official and was a federal Labor Party candidate at the 2001 election. Geraldine Doogue on Saturday Breakfast failed to disclose during an interview on the terrorist group Hezbollah with a commentator from a Lebanese TV station that the TV station was owned and operated by the very same Hezbollah.

That brings me to the issue of how the ABC describe terrorism. They do not want to label anyone—labels are not helpful. First the ABC used the old cliche ‘one man’s terrorist is another man’s freedom fighter’, as if the Bali bombers, al Qaeda or the London fanatics could ever be regarded as freedom fighters. Then they decided to be guided by the United Nations. If the UN listed a terrorist organisation the ABC would call them ‘terrorists’. But their journalists broke that rule so many times they had to get a new rule. Two dozen terrorist groups not on the UN list became ‘terrorist organisations’ according to no fewer than 20 different ABC journalists. The only times that news management did anything about it were when someone called Hezbollah or Hamas ‘terrorists’. I am still waiting for the ABC to get back to me on the difference between terrorists in southern Russia killing children in a school and terrorists in Jerusalem killing schoolchildren on a bus.

Now the ABC have a brand new rule: ‘Only call them terrorists if a third party is using the term.’ The style guide even gives an example: ‘What the Israeli government calls a “terrorist cell”.’ But guess what—since that latest new policy came in, ABC journalists have broken that rule more than 30 times. Peter Lloyd on the PM program of 13 June said ‘local terror groups the MILF and Abu Sayyaf’. There was no attribution to any third party. But what happens when the terrorists are Hamas or Hezbollah and the third party is the Israeli government? Mark Willacy on 15 July said, ‘A spokesman for Israeli Prime Minister Ariel Sharon is blaming the Palestinian Authority for the rocket attacks, saying its failure to crack down on militant groups is undermining steps towards peace.’ But the Israeli spokesman actually said: ‘The Palestinian Authority is responsible for this fatal rocket attack because it continues to refuse to take the necessary steps to fight terror. Israel has lost six people this past week to terror.’ There was nothing said about militants. And I have a significant number of similar examples in store.

Look at what ABC TV’s Behind the News program is telling children about terrorism. I would like to quote from its report on terrorism since September 11: ‘As you know, on September 11 2001 the US was attacked when four planes were hijacked and flown into the World Trade Centre, the Pentagon and a field. Many consider the people behind the attacks terrorists. Terrorists create terror or fear. They do that by using violence or threatening to use violence to persuade governments or people to make changes in society. But many governments including Australia’s think terrorism is wrong.’

I ask the question here tonight: which people in the world do not consider that those who carried out the September 11 attacks were terrorists? Let me give you one example: David Duke, the former Grand Wizard of the Ku Klux Klan. He thinks it was ‘a Zionist conspiracy’. And which governments in the world think terrorism is all right? There was one: Saddam Hussein’s. Remember him celebrating on the balcony with a gun? But he is gone.

Behind the News, on your ABC, our ABC, is suggesting to children that the people behind September 11 were not necessarily terrorists and that terrorism is not necessarily wrong. I would urge Mr Russell Balding, the Managing Director of the ABC, to get serious about terrorism. He could do worse than take the advice tendered on one of his own shows, Lateline, by the executive director of the United Nations counter-terror agency, Mr Javier Ruperez:

quote.para: There is not one single action that could be construed as being enough in the fight against terrorism. I think that we have to try and put together a number of different actions—political, legal, financial, philosophical ...

speech.para: Refusing to call a terrorist a terrorist and instead using their preferred terms, like ‘militant’, plays straight into the hands of the terrorists. Matt Brown even called al-Qaeda ‘militants’ the other day. And why does the ABC consider that ‘terrorist’ is a label but ‘militant’ is not? Then there is ‘so-called’. We get ‘the so-called war on terrorism’ on the ABC, but you never hear, for instance, ‘the so-called human shield Donna Mulhearn’ on Australian Story. Perhaps the next ABC policy will be ‘the so-called war on alleged militancy’.

There is nothing ‘so-called’ about the war being waged against the Howard government by one Lindsay McDougall, a sometime musician and now ‘the doctor’ from Triple J morning show Jay and the Doctor. Fresh from his spectacularly unsuccessful election CD Rock Against Howard, with such memorable little ditties as ‘John Howard, gun him down’, Mr McDougall moved on to his post-election strategy to get the ‘c***’—again, I will not say the word, but he did—‘and his Treasurer mate’ at the next election.

The delighted management at the ABC rewarded this fellow traveller with a plum full-time job on the youth network. Mr McDougall has had a longstanding and publicly stated opposition to government immigration policies. Rather than play music and keep his angry left-wing political opinions to himself, we now find the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, my colleague here, Senator Vanstone, is nominated on Mr McDougall’s show as the Triple J ‘Friday F**kwit’. On a daily basis we get snide comments about the Howard government, and yet the ABC appointed Mr McDougall knowing he had a clear political agenda to support the Australian Democrats and the ALP—more left-wing bias served up to Australia’s young people by ‘our’ ABC.

Mr Cameron, the news boss, made it very clear to journalists in various memos that injudicious behaviour will create an impression that the ABC is biased. It is much more than an impression. I intend to continue to ask the ABC managing director, Russell Balding, for an explanation about all of this and for some definite action in terms of avoiding continuation of bias within the ABC.

talk.start.para: (Senator Watson)—I remind you that your views were broadcast tonight on the ABC.

—On Sunday, 3 July, Australia lost one of its greatest Aboriginal ambassadors, spokesmen and champions of reconciliation. Mr W Rubuntja passed away in Alice Springs that night—peacefully, I might add, but after a rather long illness. In his own words:

quote.para: When they see us dance we can celebrate that we all belong to the songs that cross the whole of this country.

speech.para: Tonight I want to pay special tribute to Mr W Rubuntja, a humble and dignified man of many talents. While he is universally known by his first name, with regard to the wishes of his family and the Arrernte cultural practice I will refer to him here as ‘Mr Rubuntja’. His life and achievements were commemorated at the Northern Territory state funeral in Alice Springs on 21 July this year. I want to commend the Northern Territory government for instigating the state funeral on his behalf. It is well worth reading the story of his life in a book called The Town Grew Up Dancing, to learn more about the remarkable man and his country.

I was privileged to be present at the launch of this book, which was cowritten by Jenny Green, at the Araleun arts centre in 2002. It is a light-hearted but very insightful story about the efforts and achievements of this man. It is worth reading because it gives you a chance to read in his own words some anecdotes that Mr Rubuntja provided during the writing of this book. It is a great insight into the Aboriginal history and development of Central Australia. He was one of our great inclusive leaders, who did so much to shape the nation. While he was little known outside Central Australia, where he passed away recently—I understand he owned nothing more than the clothes he was in when he died—he certainly had a lot of respect and love from those who knew him.

His humanity, wit, grace, charm and sense of humour dominated the eulogies at the state funeral, which I attended. His deep cultural knowledge as a senior Arrernte lawman and a philosophical inclusiveness meant he was able to bring people together, both black and white, to work for a better future. In his later years he was a dignified, enigmatic presence around Alice Springs, always in his suit jacket and that crumpled, old, little, brown, brimmed hat.

Mr Rubuntja was born in the mid-twenties at Burt Creek, to the north-west of Alice Springs. He grew up as a rascally kid in and around the young frontier town of Alice Springs. His upbringing incorporated an Arrernte world view of country, ceremony and bush knowledge mixed together with doses of Lutheran and Catholic Christianity, and Hollywood cowboy movies at the cinema on Saturdays, he would say. As a young man he worked variously as a drover, stock camp boss, interpreter, house builder, gardener and cook. He took up painting, led by the example of and inspired by his uncle Albert Namatjira. It led to a talent in both the western landscape and the western desert ‘dot’ styles, drawing on his intimate knowledge of the Arrernte stories about the land.

He was a respected and collected artist in his own right, with works hung in the National Gallery of Australia, the Robert Holmes a Court collection and many other collections throughout this land. His work is also on display here in Parliament House in the form of the Barunga Statement. He was one of the artists and leaders who painted the culturally and politically charged Barunga Statement in 1988. It called for respect for Aboriginal culture and laws to be enshrined in a treaty between Indigenous people and the Australian nation.

He was acclaimed in the recent anniversary celebrations in Alice Springs of two organisations formed in the 1970s to address Aboriginal people’s needs. Those organisations were the Tangentyere Council and the Central Land Council. He was at the forefront of the battle to win basic services, land and housing for Aboriginal people living on the outskirts of Alice Springs in the 1970s. These fringe dwellers lived in appalling conditions, with no rights to services as basic as water, let alone housing and education. Tangentyere Council was formed to fight on behalf of the fringe dwellers and Mr Rubuntja was its first president. A long struggle against prejudice led to the eventual granting of special leases, housing and other services for these ‘town campers’.

Today, Tangentyere Council is the service organisation for the 18 Alice Springs Aboriginal housing associations. It is one of the largest organisations in Alice Springs. It still deals with the endemic poverty and disadvantage of many Aboriginal residents of Alice Springs and their extended families from the bush. However, Tangentyere has had its wins and success stories and Aboriginal people are now directly involved in providing services and deciding their future. Mr Rubuntja was at the forefront of that movement.

He was also involved with setting up the Yeperenye School in Alice Springs, an independent Aboriginal school where students learn in English and in their own language. In fact, my very first memory of meeting Mr Rubuntja in 1999 was in fact at one of the Yeperenye School fetes. He used to always refer to people who he liked as ‘good little boys’ and ‘good little girls’. The first time I met him, I was give the distinguished compliment of being ‘a special good little girl’. I guess that means I got his tick of approval.

Intertwined with the struggle for the rights of fringe dwellers in the 1970s, Mr Rubuntja also led the struggle for land rights, reconciliation and the protection of sacred sites. The Northern Territory enjoys the strongest Aboriginal land rights regime in Australia. This is partly due to Mr Rubuntja’s tireless efforts in bringing together Aboriginal people from across the Territory. Much was made at his funeral of his ability to reconcile differing points of view and to show respect to opponents. All his skills were needed to bring people together in the meetings and lobbying that preceded the Northern Territory Aboriginal Land Rights Act. The legislation was drafted under the Whitlam government but not passed before the sacking of that government. Malcolm Fraser was under huge pressure from within his coalition to back away from it.

The Central Land Council’s lawyer at the time, now Justice Geoff Eames QC, spoke at the funeral. He told of the meeting in Canberra between Mr Rubuntja, with other Aboriginal leaders, and Malcolm Fraser when the Land Rights Act was in the balance. Justice Eames related the dignity and the forcefulness with which Mr Rubuntja put his people’s case, which included the revelation of a sacred object he was authorised to bring to show the rightness of the cause. Justice Eames said it was one of the most profound and significant meetings in the history of Northern Territory land rights. Malcolm Fraser stood by his commitments given at the meeting, despite enormous pressure, and the act was passed with few amendments. It is unfortunate that some of Mr Fraser’s successors in the coalition are now fighting to undo this work.

Mr Rubuntja served as chairman of the Central Land Council between 1976 and 1980 and again from 1985 to 1988, overseeing the process of Aboriginal people winning back rights to some of their traditional lands. His campaigning led him to meet all the Australian prime ministers since Fraser. He even met the Pope and the Queen. In his later years, he would happily boast about the meetings and happily throw these into anecdotes while entertaining his audience.

His detailed cultural knowledge as a senior Arrernte lawman meant he was also at the forefront of the struggle to protect sacred sites in and around Alice Springs. He was chairman of the Northern Territory Aboriginal Sacred Sites Authority from 1983 to 1985. This often led to frustration and conflict with the Country Liberal Party government of the Northern Territory. Thankfully, many sites were saved and are still part of the rich cultural landscape of the centre. Mr Rubuntja was a natural choice as one of the first members of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation set up in 1991. He served two terms on the council, which aimed so high but which was left largely disowned by the new federal government in 1996.

Mr Rubuntja embodied reconciliation through his words and deeds. Though he was part of some of the most contentious and bitter debates, he was never bitter. He said that all children, black or white, born in Alice Springs were little Yeperenyes, or caterpillars, the local dreaming of Alice. To his wife Cynthia and her family, I extend my condolences. I would like to conclude with Mr Rubuntja’s words from 1988, quoted in the book The Town Grew Up Dancing and by the Central Land Council in their statement on his death. They are as meaningful now as they were in the bicentennial year. He said:

quote.para: Today there are lots of people living in this country, people who have come from all over the world. We don’t call them foreigners. We don’t ask, ‘Where’s your country? Where’s your father from?’ They have been born here. Their mother’s blood is in this country. This is their country too now. So, all of us have to live together. We have to look after each other. We have to share this country. And this means respecting each other’s laws and culture. We have to work out a way of sharing this country. But there has to be an understanding of, and respect of our culture and law.

speech.para: Mr Rubuntja, may you rest in peace. This country has lost a wonderful Indigenous man.

talk.start.para: —I would like to speak about a few issues of significance to my electorate and home state of Queensland. This weekend we have a couple of by-elections in and around Brisbane, one on the south side of Brisbane and the other in the electorate of Redcliffe—which is the city of Redcliffe—following the retirement of the former Speaker, Mr Ray Hollis. Incidentally, he was a Democrats Senate candidate back in the 1980s before shifting across to serve the people of Redcliffe for over a decade as a Labor member.

speech.para: Redcliffe has the distinction of perhaps being associated with the longest, continuing broken political promise in Queensland history concerning the repeated pledge for more than a century—by governments of all colours—to build a rail link from Brisbane to the Redcliffe Peninsula. I believe there are now more than ever very strong economic, traffic management, environmental, health and social reasons why that rail link should be built. A few years ago, the current Queensland state government—the Beattie Labor government—suggested that the time had come and it was finally going to be built. The diversion or the link from the main northern railway and the northern suburbs would now be built across to Deception Bay and Redcliffe. Initial signalling of the proposal was even put in for assessment under the federal Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act. But nothing happened.

A few years later, the nomination for assessment was quietly withdrawn and the state government, once again, backed away from proposing to build that railway, instead relying on the time-honoured—and I might say regularly failing—approach of further widening what is now an extremely wide and very busy Bruce Highway. It should be emphasised that the suburbs adjoining and leading into the city of Redcliffe—such as a Murrumba Downs, Mango Hill and Deception Bay itself—are some of the fastest growing regions in Queensland and indeed in Australia. In the next 15 years it is expected that another 60,000 people will move into that area and all of them will have to either drive to the main existing railway and park there or drive all the way to Brisbane using that ever busier Bruce Highway.

The benefits of having a rail option for people in those areas is blindingly obvious. We are seeing a huge usage of the rail link that was put in and expanded on the Gold Coast a few years ago. That rail link was torn up many years ago and, lo and behold, a couple of decades later the government and the taxpayers had to pay to rebuild the whole thing. It is proving to be immensely popular. I think the economics of a railway clearly add up on a whole lot of fronts compared to all the other options, and I believe it is time for the railway to go ahead. Clearly, this Saturday provides a good opportunity for the people of Redcliffe to cast a vote in favour of sending a signal to all the political parties that are running that a railway is the way to go. They can still do that. There is a candidate running—who I think is at the top of the ballot paper—specifically on that issue. People can then pass on their preferences, if they wish, to another party.

I also take the opportunity to mention another issue of significance to Redcliffe, which is the historic Hornibrook Bridge. It was built in 1935. It is almost two kilometres long. It is one of the oldest and longest timber girder bridges in Australia. My father—who was a civil engineer—whilst not involved in the construction of this specific bridge, worked for Hornibrook for many years. As a youngster, I recall driving to Redcliffe for holidays and going over the old Hornibrook Bridge and stopping to pay the toll at the booth at the northern end of the bridge. From memory, I think it was 10c at that time. Eventually, the toll was dropped when the bridge was paid for. That bridge was taken out of use for traffic when the Houghton Highway was built some time ago, and there are proposals to build a duplicate bridge next to the Houghton Highway. It is now suggested that, because of the cost of maintaining the historic Hornibrook Bridge, it should be largely dismantled, apart from small parts.

The bridge is still widely used by many fishing people and also by cyclists, joggers and walkers. It is worth preserving. We have had what I think are quite spurious suggestions as to why it should be removed, including the fact that people are fishing off the bridge and, if they have a problem, the bridge is sufficiently old that it is not possible for emergency vehicles to drive along it. That might be a problem but, frankly, people go fishing in boats and in all sorts of remote places and if you are going to require people to always be somewhere where you can drive an ambulance right beside them before they can go fishing then they will not be going fishing in many places.

Arguments like that are really just looking for excuses to remove the bridge. Speaking as someone who has spent their whole life in Brisbane, and as a regular visitor to Redcliffe in my early childhood, that bridge is an iconic part of the south-east corner of Brisbane and Redcliffe and connects those two cities. Redcliffe is the location where people first tried to settle in the region when the penal colony was first proposed around Moreton Bay, before it moved to the area where the city now stands on the Brisbane River. The bridge linking Redcliffe Peninsula and Brisbane is an iconic one. It is a historic one of great heritage value. Whilst I recognise that there will be a cost to maintain it, I think that that relatively small cost is one worth spending to maintain the heritage value of a bridge that will be 70 years old this year.

Those sorts of links with the past are, I believe, worth preserving. Whilst ever such bridges are safe for public usage, it is good if people can make use of them. It would be a sad time if that bridge was removed without extremely good cause. I know many people in the Redcliffe City Council are keen to see whether there are still ways to try to preserve that bridge. As a representative of the state of Queensland, I would like to express support for them. It is important that that link with the past and with Redcliffe be maintained. It would be a good juxtaposition to have that 70-year-old historic bridge maintained into the future alongside the historic century-old promise to build a rail link to Redcliffe.

One piece of heritage I think we could dispense with is that of it being the oldest broken promise in Queensland political history. The time has come for the new railway to be put in to the Redcliffe Peninsula and for the old historic bridge to remind us of how simply building more bridges and more roads is not always the way to go. There are alternatives, such as rail, to promote and that clearly is a more economically viable alternative than continually expanding the size and width of roads or trying other mechanisms such as busways et cetera.

The by-elections this weekend will provide a good opportunity to focus on those particular issues for the people of Redcliffe. Whatever the results of the Redcliffe by-election and the particular needs, I might also say, of the Redcliffe Hospital—yet another local hospital that is a victim of some of the problems with health and hospital mismanagement in Queensland—I will be continuing to push for some of those issues of importance to the people of the Redcliffe area and people in the south-east corner of Queensland.
