The following document was tabled pursuant to the order of the Senate of 30 May 1996, as amended:

quote.para: Indexed lists of departmental and agency files for the period 1 January to 30 June 2005—Statement of compliance—Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

subdebateinfo.title: Civil Aviation Safety Authority: Safety Seminars

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 23 February 2005:

quote.para: With reference to page 39 of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) Annual report for 2003-04:

item.para: What steps have been taken to assess the effectiveness of CASA safety seminars?
What research has been undertaken to determine the reason for the overall reduction of 14.8 per cent in attendance at CASA safety seminars?
Would the Minister provide a copy of the results of any research undertaken; if not, why not.

talker.name: Campbell, Sen Ian
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage
talker.name: Senator Ian Campbell

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator’s question:

item.para: In 2004, CASA began surveying course participants in order to determine the effectiveness of its safety seminars. Results from the March 2005 quarterly report indicate that 38% of those participants surveyed considered their knowledge of safety responsibilities to be good to extremely good. Upon completion of a CASA safety seminar, this figure had increased to 88%. A copy of these results is attached for information.
CASA anticipates that by December 2005, all course participants will be routinely surveyed.

Although no formal research has been undertaken to determine the reason for the overall reduction in attendance at safety seminars, I am advised that CASA is currently planning a series of focus groups with pilots and engineers from capital cities and regional locations to identify the motivational factors that affect attendance. CASA will also use the focus groups to discuss such issues as seminar content and location.

Additionally, in the March/April edition of Flight Safety Australia, CASA distributed a safety seminar questionnaire aimed at obtaining information on preferred timing, format and location of seminars in order to improve attendance figures.
As noted earlier, the Authority has not undertaken any formal research to determine the reason for the overall reduction in attendance at safety seminars. Accordingly, no results are available.

quote.para: ASP Program Delivery Seminars Evaluation: 2004/05.

A total of 149 participants completed evaluation sheets provided at three locations where the seminars were held: Sydney (78), Adelaide (30) and Albury (41). This analysis summarises the participants’ views on the usefulness of the Seminars.
Pre and Post - Seminar Knowledge
. 28% rated their pre-course knowledge as ‘poor’ or ‘very poor’ while 38% thought it was ‘good’ to ‘extremely good’ (see Fig 1).
. 3% rated their post seminar knowledge as ‘poor’ while 88% described it as ‘good’ to ‘extremely good’; furthermore, over 54% rated the Seminars as ‘ very good’ (cf Fig 2).
. Comparison of pre - and post- seminar ratings suggest a positive shift in knowledge acquisition.

para.inline: Relevance and ability to apply knowledge

quote.para: . Regarding participants view about relevance of the Seminars, 83% thought they were ‘very relevant’ or ‘extremely relevant’.

. Of the 83% of the participants who indicated the course was ‘relevant’ to ‘extremely relevant’ the majority (over 90%) felt confident they could apply the knowledge gained to their aviation related jobs. (see Table 2 Appendix 1). This pattern is the same in all three cities.
. Again almost 89% of these participants said they will be more effective in their aviation activities as a result of attending the Seminars (see Table 3 Appendix 1.)
Relevance and Repeated and Attendance

. 74% of respondents has had at least one previous attendance at the Seminars. For the majority of these participants (90%), the relevance of the Seminars to their aviation work ranged from ‘good’ to ‘extremely good’ perhaps explaining their repeated attendance (see Table 1)
. Also of those who claimed to have attended one or more of the Seminars in the past, 70 per cent expressed the desire to attend future Seminars (cf Table.1, Appendix 1).
. Finally, 5 out of the 6 who attended for the first time said they will attend future ones.
. Over all there is significant evidence based on the participants’ evaluation to indicate usefulness of the Seminars.

. However, the relatively small proportion of participants (about 5%) indicating first time attendance could imply that there is a greater need for efforts to reach targets who have not participated before. Note too, that many of the first timers have expressed the desire to attend future Seminars.
APPENDIX 1:
Table 1: Previous Attendance by Future Attendance
Table 2: Relevance by Ability to Apply Knowledge
Table 3: Relevance by Perceived Increased Effectiveness at Aviation Tasks

subdebateinfo.title: Civil Aviation Safety Authority: Regulatory Services

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 23 February 2005:

item.para: For each of the past two financial years, what action has been taken to assess industry satisfaction with the Civil Aviation Safety Authority’s (CASA) performance in relation to aviation regulatory services (Output 4), with particular reference to:

item.label: (a)
item.para: the number of industry participants invited to participate in surveys;

item.label: (b)
item.para: the number of respondents;

item.label: (c)
item.para: the frequency with which surveys are conducted; and

item.label: (d)
item.para: the cost of surveys.
Would the Minister provide a copy of the most recent survey questionnaire; if not, why not.
Would the Minister provide a copy of the latest survey results; if not, why not.
Were these surveys conducted internally or externally; if the surveys were conducted externally:

item.label: (a)
item.para: who provided the survey/research services; and

item.label: (b)
item.para: was the provider of the survey/research services selected by open tender; if not, how was the provider selected?

talker.name: Campbell, Sen Ian
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage
talker.name: Senator Ian Campbell

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator’s question:

item.para: Industry’s satisfaction with the regulatory services provided by CASA is assessed through a ‘Client Satisfaction Survey' distributed by the CASA Service Centre upon completion of a regulatory service in relation to Air Operator’s Certificates or Certificates of Approval. The initial survey was conducted in January 2004 for all CASA certificates issued in the period July - November 2003. The distribution of surveys is dependent upon the number of certificates issued for the applicable period. The answer to Question 1, a-b appears in the table below.
A copy of the most recent survey questionnaire is attached for information. (Attachment A)

A copy of the latest survey resultsfor the 3rd Quarter of 2004/05 is at attachment B. If an applicant has been issued more than one certificate in a given survey period, they will only receive one survey questionnaire. Survey questionnaires are not sent to certificate holders that have had their certificates changed following regulatory action or if a certificate is re-issued as a result an administrative error.

item.label: (4) (a)
item.para: and (b). The surveys are conducted internally from within the CASA Service Centre as part of its regulatory function and no specific cost breakdowns are kept.

quote.para: Attachment A
<OPERATOR NAME>
<OPERATOR ADDRESS>
Dear Operator
Re: CASA Service Centre Customer Satisfaction Survey
As a valued client we need your help!

The CASA Service Centre has been in operation now for just over 3 years. In that time we have made considerable improvements to the way CASA handles applications for Air Operator Certificates, Certificate Of Approvals, Instrument Of Appointments and Approved Testing Officers. To assist us as we continue to improve the way the Service Centre deals with you, please take a moment to complete this survey.
Your input is most appreciated.
(signed)
Reg Perkins
General Manager (Acting)
Regulatory Services Division
5 July 2005

entry.para: Please select the type of Certificate you recently applied for:

quote.para: Please indicate your level of satisfaction during your dealings with the CASA Service Centre.

entry.para: The response time by the Service Centre when requesting assistance?
Courtesy of the Service Centre staff in assisting you?
Service Centre staff's ability to assist you in identifying and solving problems/issues?
Service Centre staff's timeliness in following up on an issue that could not be solved on your first contact?
Your overall satisfaction with the service you received?

quote.para: Any comments?
Attachment B

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer, upon notice, on 14 March 2005:

quote.para: With respect to the Australian Taxation Office (ATO):

item.para: For the last calendar or financial year for which the ATO has records:
what is the total number of sick leave days taken by the ATO’s employees; and
for that same period, what was the average number of sick leave days taken per full-time equivalent employee of the ATO.
Under the ATO’s Certified Agreement or individual contracts, what is the sick leave entitlement allowable to employees as part of their terms of employment.
Does the ATO monitor and review its employees’ use of their sick leave entitlement.

talker.name: Coonan, Sen Helen
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts
talker.name: Senator Coonan

talk.start.para: —As this question deals with matters of taxation administration, I asked the Commissioner of Taxation for advice:

item.label: (1) (a)
item.para: For the period 1 July 2003 to 30 June 2004 a total of 206,899.21 sick leave days have been taken by ATO employees.
For the period 1 July 2004 to 30 April 2005 a total of 169,052.56 sick leave days have been taken by ATO employees.

The ATO has two Agency Agreements in place. The ATO (General Employees) Agreement covers staff at the Administrative Public Service Level 1 through to employees at the Executive Level 1. The ATO (Executive Level 2) Agreement covers employees at this level only.
The ATO (General Employees) Agreement
Employees who are engaged for a period of at least 12 months will get an entitlement to 110 hours and 15 minutes sick leave on full pay (3 weeks) on the date of their engagement.
All employees will accrue an additional entitlement of 110 hours and 15 minutes sick leave on full pay on each anniversary of their engagement.
Any leave credits not used in a year will accumulate as additional entitlements accrue.
Part Time Employees leave is accrued on a pro rata basis in line with the employees specified hours.
The ATO (Executive Level 2) Agreement

EL2 employees are allocated 147 hours (4 weeks) Personal leave to cover personal illness, bereavement or to provide short term care for a member of their immediate family or household or another person for whom they have a caring responsibility.
Provisions with respect to personal illness (sick leave) are generally the same as the provisions outlined above.
Yes.

subdebateinfo.title: Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs: Fraud

quote.para: In each of the financial years 2000-01, 2001-02, 2002-03, 2003-04 and 2004-05 to date, how many cases of fraud against the department have been a result of forged documentation including any of the following: (a) forged drivers’ licenses; (b) forged birth certificates; (c) forged Australian citizenship papers; (d) forged passports, either Australian or other nationalities (please specify); and (e) forged marriage certificates, either Australian or other nationalities (please specify).

talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Indigenous Affairs
talker.name: Senator Vanstone

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator’s question is as follows:

quote.para: My Department does not record or keep statistics on instances of fraud detected by types of forged document as specified in your question.

subdebateinfo.title: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations: Overseas Travel

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, upon notice, on 4 May 2005:

quote.para: For each financial year since 2000-01 to 2004-05 to date:

item.label: (1) (a)
item.para: What overseas travel was undertaken by the Minister; (b) what was the purpose of the Minister’s visit; (c) when did the Minister depart Australia; (d) who travelled with the Minister; and (e) when did the Minister return to Australia.

item.label: (2) (a)
item.para: Who did the Minister meet during the visit; and (b) what were the times and dates of each meeting.

item.label: (3) (a)
item.para: On how many of these trips was the Minister accompanied by a business delegation; and (b) can details be provided of any delegation accompanying the Minister.

subdebateinfo.title: Immigration: Christmas Island Reception and Processing Centre

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 6 June 2005:

item.para: Since July 2003, on what date(s) has the Immigration Detention Advisory Group (IDAG) visited the temporary Immigration Reception and Processing Centre on Christmas Island.
On each occasion, which member(s) of the IDAG participated in the visit.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Indigenous Affairs
talker.name: Senator Vanstone

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator’s question is as follows:

item.para: Members of the Immigration Detention Advisory Group (IDAG) visited the temporary Christmas Island Immigration Reception and Processing Centre (CI IRPC), on 26 September 2003 and the 25 and 26 February 2005. A scheduled visit on 26 November 2004 was abandoned due to an aircraft malfunction.

On 26 September 2003, IDAG members Air Marshal Ray Funnell AC (Retd), Dr Mohammed Taha Alsalami, and Mr Paris Aristotle visited the temporary CI IRPC. On 25 and 26 February 2005, the IDAG Chair the Hon John Hodges and IDAG members Sister Loreto Conroy, Dr Mohammed Taha Alsalami, Air Marshal Ray Funnell AC (Retd) and Major General Warren Glenny AO RFD ED (Retd) visited the temporary CI IRPC.

subdebateinfo.title: Immigration: Christmas Island Reception and Processing Centre

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 6 June 2005:

quote.para: For each month since July 2003: (a) how many detainees held at the temporary Immigration Reception and Processing Centre on Christmas Island have been subjected to constant observation and/or have had their movement restricted; and (b) how many of these detainees were children aged 17 years or younger.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Indigenous Affairs
talker.name: Senator Vanstone

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator’s question is as follows:

item.label: (a)
item.para: No Christmas Island IRPC detainees have been placed on constant observation or restricted movements.

The Suicide and Self-Harm Prevention Policy (SASH) group is a high level working group established in each centre under the direction of the DSP General Manager which determines, monitors and reviews all policies, processes and approaches to the issue of self-harm. The group comprises management representatives from the DSP and its contracted on-site medical staff (including psychological and psychiatric services), and the department. The group meets regularly to discuss options for the most appropriate way to care for detainees who may have been identified as at risk of self harm.
Depending on the level of need, detainees may be placed on constant, intensive, random, 30 or 60 minute watch observation.
Due to the infrastructure at Christmas Island IRPC, there is no facility to undertake constant observation of detainees.

In addition, due to the nature and layout of the Christmas Island IRPC, persons placed on SASH watch are restricted only to non-participation in external escorts apart from medical and religious escorts. This is a relatively small facility and detainees on SASH watch can more easily be unobtrusively observed by officers during the course of the day. They continue to receive visits and movements within the centre itself are not restricted in any manner.

item.label: (b)
item.para: No children aged 17 or under have been subjected to constant observation and/or restricted movement.

subdebateinfo.title: Immigration: Christmas Island Reception and Processing Centre

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 6 June 2005:

quote.para: With reference to the Government’s response to concerns raised in the Immigration Detention Advisory Committee report about the temporary Immigration Reception and Processing Centre (IRPC) on Christmas Island relating to the provision of desk lamps for children detained at the centre:

item.label: (1) (a)
item.para: What relevant Australian standards were applied as justification for denying the installation of reading lamps in detainees’ rooms; and (b) can a copy be provided of the relevant design standards.

item.label: (2) (a)
item.para: Who approved the room specifications allowing one power point per room; and (b) can double adaptors be used to facilitate the use of a reading lamp and another electrical appliance in detainees’ rooms up to the safe amperage rating; if not, why not.

Has the department held discussions with its immigration detention service provider about options to upgrade lighting in detainees’ rooms; if not, why not; if so (a) when did those discussions commence; (b) who participated in those discussions; (c) what options were discussed; and (d) how were detainees consulted.
Was lighting upgraded; if so, when and how was it upgraded, if not; why not.

Does the Minister stand by the claim that ‘for safety reasons electrical appliances may only be introduced into detention centres with prior approval and after a successful electrical test and tagging.’

Can a schedule be provided, by year since commencement of the IRPC, of all electrical devices introduced into the temporary IRPC on Christmas Island, including but not necessarily limited to desk lamps, air-conditioners, electric fans, computers, printer, scanners, photocopiers, electric staplers, mobile telephone chargers, telephone answering machines, toasters, electric jugs, microwaves, video players, CD players, DVD players and refrigerators for use by: (a) the department; (b) the department’s immigration detention service provider; and (c) subcontractors engaged by department’s immigration detention service provider.

item.label: (7) (a)
item.para: For each item (in 6 above), would the Minister advise: (i) the date of approval, (ii) the name of the responsible decision-maker, (iii) the date of electrical testing, (iv) the business name of the tester, (v) the cost of the test; and (b) will the Minister: (i) identify who met that cost, and (ii) disclose whether a tag is attached to the electrical item.

Can a schedule be provided of all electrical items sought to be admitted into the detention centre that have not been admitted due to the failure to obtain prior approval, and/or failure to produce evidence of successful electrical testing and certification for use by: (a) the department (b) the department’s immigration detention service provider; and (c) subcontractors engaged by department’s immigration detention service provider.

Can a schedule be provided of all electrical items sought to be admitted into the detention centre that have not been admitted due to the failure to obtain prior approval and/or failure to produce evidence of successful electrical testing and certification for use by detainees or visitors.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Indigenous Affairs
talker.name: Senator Vanstone

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator’s question is as follows:

item.label: (1) (a)
item.para: Testing and tagging is outlined in the Australian Standard/New Zealand Standard AS:NZS 3760:2000 entitled In Service Safety Inspection and Testing of Electrical Equipment. (b) A copy is available from the Seante Table Office.

item.label: (2) (a)
item.para: As the buildings were purchased second-hand, the Department of Immigration, Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) does not have information on who approved the room specifications. (b) Double power-points have now been installed in all the rooms.

In early March 2005, the DIMIA Centre Manager and the Detention Service Provider (DSP) Maintenance Officer had discussions relating to the options of a lighting upgrade in detainee rooms. (a) Early March 2005. (b) The DIMIA Centre Manager and the DSP Maintenance Officer participated in these discussions. (c) The option of installing wall mounted fluorescent lights was discussed. (d) There was no formal consultation with the detainees.
Lighting was upgraded through the installation of higher wattage light bulbs after the Immigration Detention Advisory Group, raised the matter.
Yes.
The requested schedule is attached.
Some of the information requested would require an examination of extensive records and it is an unreasonable diversion of resources to collect. However, the Department can advise the following:

item.label: (a) (i)
item.para: Electrical items introduced into the Christmas Island Immigration Reception and Processing Centre (IRPC) need to be tagged and tested prior to the item being allowed into the Centre, unless the item is new.

item.label: (ii)
item.para: The Department’s Facilities Management Section is the responsible decision-maker in these cases.

item.label: (iii)
item.para: The tagging and testing of electrical items in the IRPC is undertaken on an annual basis, in December of each year. Any additional items introduced into the IRPC are tagged and tested prior to being allowed into the Centre.

item.label: (iv)
item.para: Krepp Electrics is the contractor.

item.label: (v)
item.para: The cost of the annual testing electrical items at the IRPC is approximately $1100 per year.

item.label: (b) (i)
item.para: The Department meets the cost of the annual testing and tagging of the equipment.

item.label: (ii)
item.para: Tags are attached to all electrical items which are older than 12 months. Items under 12 months old are not required to be tagged.
A record is not kept of items refused entry.
A record is not kept of items refused entry. However, the DSP has informed the Department that it is aware of two items that have been refused.
A desk lamp which a visitor presented to a detainee was returned to the visitor when it failed a safety check.
A second-hand Television was presented without an electrical tag and the visitor was informed that it needed testing and tagging prior to a detainee being able to use it.

quote.para: SCHEDULE OF APPLIANCE PURCHASES FOR CIIRPC BY DATE AS AT 17 JUNE 2005

subdebateinfo.title: Immigration: Christmas Island Reception and Processing Centre

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 6 June 2005:

quote.para: When were children detained at the temporary Immigration Reception and Processing Centre on Christmas Island provided with desks for homework.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Indigenous Affairs
talker.name: Senator Vanstone

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator’s question is as follows:

quote.para: On 10 October 2004, a request for desks was received from one of the detainee high school students.

On 22 October 2004, a number of desks were borrowed from the Christmas Island District High School. The desks were cleaned and some minor repairs undertaken at the Christmas Island IRPC. The desks were then given to the students and placed in their residential accommodation a short time later.
A letter of thanks was subsequently sent to the school authorities by the Detention Services Provider.

subdebateinfo.title: Immigration: Christmas Island Reception and Processing Centre

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 6 June 2005:

item.para: Does the department, or the department’s immigration detention service provider, maintain a record of visitors refused entry to the temporary Immigration Reception and Processing Centre (IRPC) on Christmas Island, and a record of the reasons for the decision.

item.label: (2) (a)
item.para: If a record is maintained, by month: (i) how many individual visits have been refused since the centre commenced operation, and (ii) for what reasons have such visits been refused; and (b) if no record is maintained, why not.
On what dates, and for what reasons, have visiting sessions at the IRPC been: (a) cancelled; (b) curtailed; and (c) rescheduled.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Indigenous Affairs
talker.name: Senator Vanstone

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator’s question is as follows:

quote.para: It should be noted that the response below is based on records held on the current Detention Services Provider (DSP) computer system, Immigration Services Information System (ISIS) in use at Christmas Island since 21 June 2004. Prior to the current DSP entering into the detention services contract with the department, records were held on paper files. The department does not have this information readily available and to collate this information would involve a manual examination of individual files and is an unreasonable diversion of departmental resources.

item.para: A record of any refused visit is maintained on the DSP computer system, ISIS. An incident report detailing why the visit was denied is created and reported to the department.
There are no records to indicate that any individual visits to detainees have been refused at Christmas Island IRPC.

item.label: (3) (a)
item.para: Visits have been cancelled as a result of visitors’ non-attendance on
19 August 2004;
31 December 2004;
6 January 2005; and
1 June 2005.
On 10 September 2004, a visit was cancelled by a detainee who did not wish to participate in the visit.

item.label: (b)
item.para: On 8 September 2004, a visit was terminated due to wet weather.

As Christmas Island IRPC is a temporary facility and does not have a dedicated visits area, visits are held in the covered areas (cabanas) of a vacant compound. At the time of this specific visit, this vacant compound was a construction zone and was not accessible to visitors and detainees. To allow visits to continue during this period a table was placed in the administration area with some cover. This cover did not, however, allow for adequate protection during storms. This was the second time the visitor had attended for the day; a prior visit had already been completed. The second visit commenced and was terminated due to wet weather.

There is no information available to indicate that any visits at Christmas Island IRPC have been rescheduled. It is possible that the five planned visits referred to in (3)(a) above were rescheduled. These would be entered into ISIS as a ‘new visit’.

subdebateinfo.title: Immigration: Christmas Island Reception and Processing Centre

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 6 June 2005:

item.para: Can a copy be provided of the departmental policy document that prohibits access to e-mail by detainees at the temporary Immigration Reception and Processing Centre on Christmas Island.
What risk and security issues arise with respect to e-mail access that do not arise with respect to telephone access.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Indigenous Affairs
talker.name: Senator Vanstone

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator’s question is as follows:

item.para: Departmental policy relating to the use of computers with modems at all Immigration Detention Facilities (IDFs) is contained in the Detention Services Contract, Schedule 2 Clause 10.1.16, which provides that “sufficient computers, though without modem access, should be available” to detainees.

It would not be possible for my department or the Detention Services Provider to ensure (through monitoring) that inappropriate information was not accessed by detainees. My department has informally considered filtering options but technical advice has been that no filters would be completely effective. In addition, it would not be possible to ensure that detainees did not use e-mails or the internet to undertake criminal activities, assist in generating sur place refugee claims or create security risks, for example through the provision of detailed information relating to infrastructure.

subdebateinfo.title: Immigration: Christmas Island Reception and Processing Centre

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 6 June 2005:

quote.para: With reference to the Government’s response to concerns raised in the Immigration Detention Advisory Committee report about the temporary Immigration Reception and Processing Centre on Christmas Island relating to orders to destroy garden beds:

item.para: Which garden beds have been removed due to the department’s concerns about ‘safety and security’, not including garden beds removed to facilitate emergency vehicle access.

What ‘safety and security’ risk did the ‘destroyed’ garden beds pose to detainees, visitors, the department’s immigration detention service provider, the department, or the Christmas Island community.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Indigenous Affairs
talker.name: Senator Vanstone

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator’s question is as follows:

item.para: Certain gardens were removed from within the medical compound and two garden beds that were not authorised were removed from the detainee exercise area within the general compound.

Those in the medical compound were removed due to the location of the gardens along the fence line that were found to be destabilising and affecting the footings of the fence. This compound is a secure area and is not open for general access unless an officer is present.
Those in the general compound were removed as this area is used by detainees to play soccer and other sports and activities.

In addition, I can advise that, for safety and security of all detainees, a portion of a garden bed was removed to allow emergency vehicle access. Detainees had extended one of the garden beds to the point where the garden was blocking the access of emergency vehicles. Approximately two metres of garden bed was removed for this reason.

Detainees are also advised that gardens cannot be created up against any infrastructure, including buildings and fences, both for security reasons and to ensure that the care and maintenance of those structures are not obstructed.

subdebateinfo.title: Immigration: Christmas Island Reception and Processing Centre

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 6 June 2005:

quote.para: Have limits been placed on the gifting of garden produce by detainees held at the temporary Immigration Reception and Processing Centre on Christmas Island; if so: (a) what limits have been imposed; (b) when were they imposed; (c) who was the decision-maker; and (d) how were detainees consulted.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Indigenous Affairs
talker.name: Senator Vanstone

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator’s question is as follows:

item.label: (1) (a)
item.para: Limits have been imposed on the amounts of gifting of garden produce by detainees at the Christmas Island IRPC. These are:
- for visits into the IRPC - three bags per visitor/per day;

- for excursions to Church/ Fellowship/Temple – one bag per each attending detainee, to a maximum of eight bags. There is also an approved minimum of three bags per attendance if only one or two detainees attend; and
- to school – one bag per attending child per day.
The bags are large white bin liners that fit a 36 litre bin.

item.label: (b) (c)
item.para: and (d) The restrictions on the gifting of produce were imposed in January 2005 by GSL after consultation with DIMIA. Detainees were not consulted.

Gardening is intended to be a recreational activity. Fruit and vegetables grown in these gardens provide the detainees who grow them with a sense of satisfaction and achievement, and also supplement the meals that are provided by the Detention Services Provider. Seeds, fertiliser and gardening equipment are provided at no cost by the department and the Detention Services Provider to detainees.

The practice developed whereby surplus fruit and vegetables were given to visitors to reduce wastage. It was never intended nor envisaged that this fruit and these vegetables, produced at no cost to either the detainees or to those to whom they are gifted, would be in competition with the produce of islanders who have to pay for seeds, fertiliser and water. DIMIA and GSL staff at the IRPC were advised, however, that this was regularly occurring and was creating considerable resentment on the island. Consequently, GSL in consultation with DIMIA amended the policy of virtually unlimited gifting of produce to visitors, and imposed restrictions to the totals outlined above.

subdebateinfo.title: Immigration: Christmas Island Reception and Processing Centre

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 6 June 2005:

item.para: Can a copy be provided of the published rules that govern the receipt of gifts by children detained at the temporary Immigration Reception and Processing Centre (IRPC) on Christmas Island.
Would the Minister advise who is responsible for making decisions about the admission of individual gifts for children.
Can a list be provided of all gifts denied admission to the IRPC.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Indigenous Affairs
talker.name: Senator Vanstone

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator’s question is as follows:

item.para: Visitors are required to complete a visits application form/conditions of entry document, to which is attached a list of items which are not permitted into an Immigration Detention Facility (IDF). Gifts to detainees are assessed on an individual basis in accordance with that list.

In addition, the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) website provides a list of suggested items that can be sent as gifts to children and adults including reading materials, clothing, toys and a variety of games.

There are a number of factors that are taken into consideration when allowing items to be brought into an IDF. These include the capacity to store personal property at the IDF and the safety and security of the facility, the detainees and all other persons within the IDF. Items that are unlawful, pose a direct and immediate threat to the security and good order of the IDF, or have the potential to create dangerous or unsanitary conditions are not permitted.

Decisions about the admission of individual gifts to all detainees are made by the Detention Services Provider (DSP) in accordance with the list of items not permitted into IDFs. Where there is any doubt about an individual item, the DSP’s Operations Manager will make a decision about admission of an item. This may occur in consultation with the DIMIA Manager if required.

There are also limits on the amount of property detainees can have in their possession and in storage at the IDF. The property limits were developed in line with available storage space and accommodation.
There have been no recorded instances of gifts being denied admission to detainees at Christmas Island IRPC.

subdebateinfo.title: Tasmanian Electronic Commerce Centre Pty Ltd

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 16 June 2005:

item.label: (a)
item.para: When did the Commissioner of Taxation determine that Tasmanian Electronic Commerce Centre Pty Ltd (TECC) was not a charitable institution; and
when and how was the Treasurer made aware of this decision.

item.label: (a)
item.para: What did the Commissioner of Taxation deem to be the total taxation liability of TECC to the Commonwealth; and
when and how was the Treasurer made aware of this decision.
What has been the total cost to the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) of proceedings in this matter:
before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal; and
before the Federal Court of Australia.
What legal and court costs has the ATO been ordered to pay on behalf of TECC.

talker.name: Coonan, Sen Helen
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts
talker.name: Senator Coonan

talk.start.para: —As this question deals with matters of taxation administration, I asked the Commissioner of Taxation for advice:

item.label: (1) (a)
item.para: TECC was first advised that it was not a charitable institution on 31 July 1998 in response to a request for a private ruling. Subsequently, this advice was confirmed when objections against assessments for 1998, 1999 and 2000 were disallowed.
TECC was refused endorsement as an income tax exempt charity on 9 June 2004.

item.label: (b)
item.para: The Tax Office has not advised the Treasurer of its decision.

item.label: (2) (a)
item.para: The Commissioner advises me that it is inconsistent with his responsibilities under the secrecy provisions of the tax laws to provide details of the tax affairs of a specific organisation.

item.label: (b)
item.para: The Tax Office has not advised the Treasurer on this issue.

item.label: (b)
item.para: In addition, there are unquantified costs associated with time spent by Tax Office staff, and there will be fees payable to the Australian Government Solicitor that have not yet been billed.
The costs order against the Commissioner in the Federal Court is in abeyance until the Commissioner’s appeal has been determined. TECC’s costs have therefore not been quantified.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 23 June 2005:

quote.para: With reference to the Bakhtiyari family who were living in South Australia until late 2004, when they were deported:

item.para: Was Mr Ali Bakhtiyari issued with an emergency Pakistani passport prior to leaving Australia.
What travel documents were used by Mr Bakhtiyari for travel out of Australia.
On what basis was Mr Bakhtiyari verified as a Pakistani national.
What is Mr Bakhtiyari’s Pakistani identification number and date of birth.
Were his wife and 5 children issued with Pakistani documents; if so, what are their ID numbers.
Who requested these documents for the Bakhtiyari family and on what date were they requested.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Indigenous Affairs
talker.name: Senator Vanstone

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator’s question is as follows:

item.para: Yes, Mr Ali Bakhtiari was issued with an emergency Pakistani travel document by the Pakistani Government before leaving Australia.
An emergency Pakistani travel document was used by Mr Bakhtiari to depart Australia for Pakistan.
Mr Bakhtiari was verified as a Pakistani national by the Pakistani Government.

The Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs knows Mr Bakhtiari’s Pakistani identification number and his date of birth; however, this information cannot be released with out Mr Bakhtiari’s consent.
Mr Bakhtiari, his wife and children were issued with emergency Pakistani travel documents; however, details of the documents can not be released with out the family’s consent.
An officer from the department requested travel documents from the Pakistan High Commission on 17 December 2004.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 24 June 2005:

quote.para: For each of the financial years 2001-02, 2002-03, 2003-04 and 2004-05, has the Minister, the Department or any agency or statutory authority for which the Minister is responsible, made grants or other payments to business organisations and/or associations, including but not necessarily limited to peak employer groups; if so, can information be provided for each grant or other payment including: (a) the name and address of the recipient organisation; (b) the quantum and purpose of the payment; (c) the name of the programme under which the grant or other payment was funded; (d) who approved the grant or other payment; and (e) whether the grant or payment was successfully acquitted; if so when; if not, can details be provided, including actions taken to recover the grant or other payment.

talker.name: Campbell, Sen Ian
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage
talker.name: Senator Ian Campbell

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator’s question is as follows:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 30 June 2005:

quote.para: With respect to the agreements between the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) and the two tobacco companies, Philip Morris and British American Tobacco, to provide funding for corrective advertising:

item.label: (1) (a)
item.para: What advice, if any, did the department provide to the ACCC regarding the cost of developing an effective advertising campaign; and (b) can a copy of this advice be provided; if not, why not.

item.label: (2) (a)
item.para: When was this advice provided; and (b) who was consulted in developing this advice.

talker.name: Patterson, Sen Kay
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Women’s Issues
talker.name: Senator Patterson

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable senator’s question:

item.label: (1) (a)
item.para: Advice was provided on the costs associated with the National Tobacco Campaign. This was based on the Department’s experience between 1997 and 2005. (b) No, a copy of the advice cannot be provided as the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) have advised that to do so may prejudice its law enforcement investigations and/or legal proceedings. The Senator may wish to raise this issue with the ACCC directly.

item.label: (2) (a)
item.para: November 2004 and January 2005. (b) Officers of the Australian Government Department of Health and Ageing.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 30 June 2005:

item.label: (1) (a)
item.para: What advice, if any, has the department provided regarding the use of flavoured cigarettes, including fruit flavoured cigarettes; and (b) can a copy of this advice be provided; if not, why not.
When and to whom was this advice provided.

talker.name: Patterson, Sen Kay
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Women’s Issues
talker.name: Senator Patterson

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable senator’s question:

item.label: (1) (a)
item.para: I am advised that the following advice has been provided by the department:

The Australian Government does not have the constitutional power to comprehensively legislate against the manufacture and sale of tobacco products, including flavoured cigarettes. There is currently no Australian Government legislation that would prohibit the sale of these products in Australia.

The Australian Government’s aim is to reduce smoking rates and to prevent young people from taking up smoking. This is demonstrated by the commitment of $25 million, over four years, on a new anti-smoking campaign targeting young people, announced in the most recent federal Budget.

Where these products carry the current health warnings, as mandated under the Trade Practices (Consumer Product Information Standards) (Tobacco) Regulations, they comply with all Australian Government requirements in relation to labelling. From 1 March 2006, all tobacco products will include the new graphic health warnings. The powerful graphics will convey a strong and confronting message to smokers, including young people, about the harmful health consequences of smoking tobacco products.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Information is as provided above.

Advice was provided to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Ageing in April and June 2005. Responses have also been provided to correspondence sent to the Minister and to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Ageing, and to state and territory health officials on this issue.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 4 July 2005:

quote.para: With reference to the changes to the care planning Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS) items within Enhanced Primary Care (EPC):

item.para: Will the proposed changes to the prerequisites, necessary for a patient to have access to the allied health and dental care MBS items, from one plan to two plans diminish patient access to this care; if not, what assumptions were made in arriving at that conclusion.
Were allied health professionals or consumers consulted about these changes; if so can, details be provided.
What advice has the Government sought and received from professional groups about the potential impact of these changes on patient access to allied health and dental services.
What processes have been put in place to monitor access to the EPC allied health and dental care MBS items following the introduction of these new requirements.

talker.name: Patterson, Sen Kay
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Women’s Issues
talker.name: Senator Patterson

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable senator’s question:

item.para: No. The new Chronic Disease Management (CDM) items were developed in consultation with general practitioner (GP) organisations. They provide greater flexibility in care planning, while retaining the functionality of existing services. The GP management plan (GPMP) and team care arrangements (TCA) items are designed to be complementary and integrated, and together equate broadly to an EPC multidisciplinary care plan. A TCA can be prepared as a simple addition to a patient’s GPMP.

The new items maintain incentives for multidisciplinary care planning, with the total Medicare rebates for a GPMP and a TCA ($215.00) exceeding the rebate for an EPC multidisciplinary care plan ($206.75). The new items should make care planning and access to allied health services easier, as practice nurses and Aboriginal Health Workers can now play a greater role in assisting in the preparation of a GPMP and coordinating a TCA.

The changes to the EPC care planning items were proposed by the Red Tape Taskforce following its review of the Practice Incentive Program (PIP) and EPC items. The taskforce consulted widely as part of its review, including public dissemination of discussion papers through its website and direct consultation with interested parties. The detailed design of the taskforce’s recommended changes has been undertaken in close consultation with GP organisations, as is normal practice for new Medicare items. Allied health and dental organisations were briefed on the new items at a consultative group meeting on 19 May 2005.

GP groups have provided comment and input to the design of the items as per normal practice for the development of GP Medicare items. Allied health and dental groups have discussed and commented on the items through the allied health and dental care initiative’s consultative group. The Australian Physiotherapy Association has also met with the department to put forward its views.

The uptake of the CDM items and the allied health and dental care items is monitored through Health Insurance Commission (HIC) data on an ongoing basis. The impact of the introduction of the CDM items on the allied health and dental care services will be assessed after a period of operation (around two years) through uptake data, stakeholder consultation and qualitative research.
